This chamber contains more pilfered, piled-up cargo. To the west, the cave mouth opens up to the sea.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Chief Bosun Chark (a {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3}) is here separating out metal and valuables from common cargo and wreckage. He gives direction to a {@creature monstrous crab|ToB3-Lairs} with tentacles coming out of its maw (use statistics for {@creature chuul} with the changes noted below); it displays keen intelligence for a crab, and its pincers root through and tear into piles of scavenged wreckage with alarming efficiency. Two {@creature sahuagin} swim alongside the {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3|bosun}, observing operations.

If combat ensues in {@area 8|14.sc8|u}, all but the {@creature monstrous crab|ToB3-Lairs} move into the northern alcove behind piled cargo to ambush the PCs. The {@creature monstrous crab|ToB3-Lairs} moves to the southeastern part of the chamber and burrows partially down into the sand, camouflaging itself with the copious kelp in the area; it can be spotted with a successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: The {@creature monstrous crab|ToB3-Lairs|monstrous crab's} creature type is monstrosity; it only understands {@language primordial||Aquan}; its Intelligence is 8; and it does not have the Sense Magic trait or the Tentacles action. Any creature {@condition grappled} by its Pincer attack is also {@condition restrained}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Three casks of rum (worth 100 gp total); various gems and jewelry, holy symbols (worth 295 gp total); and a chest filled with bars of silver (worth 300 gp total).

As you swim down this winding cavern heading southeast, you notice the abundance of seaweed increasing as you descend the twisting tunnel. Flourishing kelp soon stretches from floor to ceiling, thickening to a jungle-like density, reducing visibility to five feet. You can't see it due to the low visibility, but, after traveling twenty to twenty-five feet, you sense the tunnel widening into a larger cavern.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature aquatic basilisk|ToB3-Lairs|aquatic basilisks} (use statistics for {@creature basilisk}, adding the Amphibious trait and a 20-foot swim speed) and three {@creature hunter shark||hunter sharks} used for mounts are stabled here. There are also 2 {@creature giant sea horse||giant sea horses} here, but they are non-hostile and tame.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: Upon the PCs' triumphant return to Wrackwater, a reclamation/repair team is immediately assembled and sent to the lighthouse. The PCs can confirm that no missing Wrackwater citizens remain alive (near the lighthouse) and that a ship indeed must have gone down somewhere outside the cove that was being scavenged from by gremlins below the lighthouse.
If you wish to further explore any of the plot threads of this adventure, "Incident at Wrackwater" can be played as a direct lead-in to "{@adventure The Salons of Mother Celeste|ToB3-Lairs|18}".

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of {@footnote 5th level|The {@adventure table of contents|ToB3-Lairs|0|The Lost Forge} says 6th level.} characters}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: High in an alpine forest lie the remains of a temple that was dedicated to dwarven gods of fire and forge. The site was abandoned by its creators after a horrific dragon attack which left most of the stone walls devastated by dragon fire. The dwarves felt the place had been cursed, and so this site became known as "The Lost Forge" by the local villagers who have long spun stories of the dwarven ghosts that haunt it.

More recently the twin warlords Kadal and Valgred have taken over the ruins with their band of orcs and ogres and made it the base of operations for their conquest of the region. Kadal quickly awoke the Lost Forge and began using it to make armor and weapons for their followers, while Valgred communed with the spirits of the ruins to gather what secrets they held. The twins then began raiding small villages in the mountains and attacking trade caravans. The local villagers pray that their homes won't be next.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i Ale Aid.}} While traveling through a mountain forest, the PCs come across a frantic and desperate dwarf guard named Jaster (N dwarf guard), who is a survivor of a dwarven ale caravan that was recently attacked. He's tracked the culprits and found where the survivors of the attack who were captured have been taken. He pleads for the PCs to aid them.

{@b {@i Village Protectors.}} While stopping to rest at a mountain village, the PCs are approached by the folk who live there and offered 100 gp each to put a stop to the twin warlords before their village is pillaged.

entries.name: Sibling Disagreements
entries: Twins Kadal (LE {@creature thursir armorer|ToB3|thursir armorer giant}) and Valgred (LE {@creature thursir hearth priestess|ToB3|thursir hearth priestess giant}) have been frequently arguing as of late—over how to proceed with their continuing conquest of the mountains. Kadal believes they should push forward with more raids, while Valgred believes they need to be more reserved and strategic with their attacks. The continual arguments have split their followers into two factions. Those who follow Valgred wear blue headbands and those that follow Kadal decorate their armor with animal skulls.

PCs who spend some time observing the occupants of the encampment quickly pick up on the tension between the two groups, though if none of them speak {@language orc||Orcish} or {@language Giant} they might not learn the specifics.

entries.name: Ruins of the Lost Forge
entries: The encampment is surrounded by a fifteen-foot-tall palisade that collapsed in a few places in the past and has been hastily patched more recently. Dark scorch marks and slashes from powerful claws are obvious on most defensive surfaces that haven't collapsed or been covered over by vines. The sounds of a loud argument in {@area 6|15.6|u}—which might eventually erupt into a fight—cover much of the noise the PCs might make while infiltrating the camp.
Aside from {@area 6|15.6|u} (which is lit by a campfire) and {@area 15|15.15|u} (which is lit by the forge), all other areas of the camp are quite dark.
For creatures who are noted as being asleep, have the PCs roll a group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check against the creature's passive {@skill Perception}.

entries.name: Kadal's Craftsmanship
entries: Any of the weapons and armor crafted by Kadal are of extremely high quality and can be sold for three times their normal listed price. The {@creature orc||orcs} all carry {@item greataxe|phb|greataxes}, and the {@creature veteran||veterans} carry a {@item battleaxe|phb} and a {@item handaxe|phb}, all crafted by Kadal.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/15.jpg}.}

Vines rise from the forest floor to cover much of a fifteen-foot-high wooden palisade. A stone building marred by large swaths of scorch marks stands at one corner of the wall. The center of the palisade in this area collapsed sometime in the distant past and has been more recently filled with stone boulders that are stacked ten feet high. Two orcs wearing blue headbands crouch near the pile of boulders playing a game of dice.

entries.name: Getting Through
entries: The PCs can attempt to get through this section of the structure by scaling the palisade with a successful DC 14 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check or squeezing past the boulder barrier with a successful DC 14 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check; a failure by 5 or more alerts the creatures in {@area 6|15.6|u} who come to investigate the source of the noise.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature orc||orcs} have been assigned as lookouts in this area outside the palisade, but both are currently playing a game of dice by the boulder barrier to pass the time. They wear blue headbands. If they see any trouble, they attempt to run to the main gate in {@area 3|15.3|u} to warn the camp.

entries.name: Hostilities
entries: An orc with skulls adorning the pauldrons of his armor approaches after the most recent round of dice has completed to ask (in {@language orc||Orcish}) for a report of any sightings. During the interaction, PCs can make a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check to discern that the new orc is not welcomed by the others and there is a sense of hostility between them.

entries.name: 2. Ogre Sleeping Area

entries: A 25-foot-tall stone building forms one side of the gate complex of this encampment. The floor is covered in with hay and detritus, and the air is stagnant with the strong odors of rotting food. The tattered remains of dwarven banners still adorn the walls, now too damaged and worn with age to read.

The building can only be entered from within the encampment. A successful DC 12 Intelligence check using {@item mason's tools|phb} or {@race dwarf||Dwarven} Stonecunning determines that though the structure presently shows significant signs of wear and neglect, it was once very well-crafted and suffered an attack sometime in the past.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature ogre||ogres} are currently napping in this chamber, one wears a blue headband and the other has a single pauldron decorated with the skull of a large bird. They have a passive {@skill Perception} of 8.

The front wooden gate is 15 feet tall and shows signs of recent repair work done by unskilled hands. The connected stone building north of the gate is missing a corner and shows signs of being burned. The inside is a mess of blackened, damaged rubble. A set of double wooden doors is the only exit from this ruined building, which leads into the encampment.

entries.name: Getting Through
entries: The front gate and the ruined building's double doors are both barricaded from the inside, requiring a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to break through.

entries.name: Hunting Traps
entries: A poison-laced hunting trap has been hidden in the rubble of the ruined tower. A creature that steps onto the trap must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d4} piercing damage and {@damage 1d6} poison damage. A successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the hidden trap.

entries.name: The Ancient Attacker
entries: A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation} or {@skill Nature}) check reveals the damage marks on the inside are claw marks. A success by 5 or more also reveals the claw marks and burnt stones were caused by a dragon (probably red, given the burn marks).
The remains of a stone tower are strewn across this area. The wooden palisade to the east of the once-imposing tower has a large gap that has been plugged by a wagon flipped onto its side.

entries.name: Difficult Sneaky Terrain
entries: Walking through the fallen tower remains is considered difficult terrain and due to the stone debris, all Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature orc||orcs} wearing armor decorated with animal skulls stand guard between the wagon and fallen tower on the outside of the palisade. They talk (in {@language orc||Orcish}) about how Valgred needs to stop getting in the way of Kadal's plans.

This large stone building is mostly destroyed, with one side completely collapsed. Dark scorch marks mar what is left of the structure. To the west of the remains there is a gap in the wooden palisade that has been hastily repaired with an overturned wagon.

entries.name: Hunting Traps
entries: There is a poisoned hunting trap (see {@area 3|15.3|u}) hidden in the debris of the ruined building.

entries.name: 6. Firepit Lounge

entries: Three large logs surround a firepit which is the only light source in the encampment. Nearby rests a haphazard stack of wooden barrels, some open, some intact, and others smashed.
If the creatures in this area have not been already alerted to investigate {@area 1|15.1|u}, also read the following:

The occupants of the firepit are embroiled in a loud argument. Four orcs, each wearing armor decorated with animal skulls, square off against one towering ogre in a blue headband who looks to be on the edge of violence.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature orc||orcs} and one {@creature orc veteran|ToB3-Lairs|veteran (orc)}—all followers of Kadal—are arguing loudly with an {@creature ogre} (obviously drunk) who is aligned with Valgred. The {@creature ogre} is suffering from the {@condition poisoned} condition due to his overindulgence of dwarven ale.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: For the {@creature veteran}, replace all mentions of "{@item longsword|phb}" with "{@item battleaxe|phb}" and "{@item shortsword|phb}" with "{@item handaxe|phb}."

entries.name: They Just Keep Coming
entries: If battle begins in this area and lasts longer than 2 rounds, Nogg from {@area 7|15.7|u} is alerted and joins the combat.

After 4 rounds of combat, Valgred hears the commotion and comes outside of her chamber in {@area 8|15.8|u} to join the battle. Any creatures with blue headbands (potentially two {@creature ogre||ogres} and one {@creature orc}) within range act as her allies for the purposes of her special ability Call for Aid.
After 1 round of combat, the orc in {@area 9|15.9|u} (loyal to Valgred) awakens and joins the fray.

entries.name: Hostilities
entries: Roll a {@dice d20} when the PCs move within sight of this area. On a 1–10 the argument continues as it is. On an 11–20 the {@creature ogre} bellows with rage and attacks the {@creature orc||orcs}. If the {@creature ogre} attacks and the PCs do not intervene, Nogg emerges from {@area 7|15.7|u} to break up the fight after 2 rounds.

This stone building is one of the least damaged in the encampment. The structure has been converted to a holding area for prisoners, with chains anchored into the western wall and the eastern portion being used as storage for recently acquired supplies.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Nogg (CE {@creature alleybasher ogre|ToB3|ogre alleybasher}), is guarding the dwarven prisoners and boxing with some empty wooden crates in the middle of the building. Nogg wears a blue headband and is itching for a fight. If she notices the PCs approach, she consumes a {@item potion of speed} that Valgred gave her.

entries.name: Rallying the Troops
entries: Ruby Runemaker (LN {@creature pike guard captain|ToB3|dwarf pike guard captain}) and six {@creature pike guard|ToB3|dwarf pike guards} are chained together on the western side of the building. If the {@creature pike guard|ToB3|dwarf pike guards} are freed, Ruby and her people are more than happy to bring the fight to the forces of the twin warlords. If the GM and/or the PCs prefer, the dwarves can head to other areas of the camp to clean up groups of enemies the PCs have not engaged yet rather than having them travel with the PCs.

entries.name: Stolen Supplies
entries: The crates in this area contain 3 {@item potion of healing||potions of healing}, a crate of salted jerky that counts as thirty days of {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, and various spices and cooking herbs (worth 100 gp total).

entries.name: 8. Valgred's Chamber
entries: A squat stone building stands relatively intact at the center of the encampment, though it too bears weathered scorch marks.

The walls of this room are decorated with tapestries, and a bed piled high with animal skins of various types takes up the southeast corner of the room. On the east side of the room, there are stacks of tomes and maps of the region spread over a table.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Valgred, a {@creature thursir hearth priestess|ToB3}, is here studying maps of the region and plotting out the locations of nearby villages and towns they might raid next.
If a fight ensues in Area 6 and lasts more than 4 rounds, Valgred realizes it might be more than just the usual tussling amongst the troops and joins the battle when she sees the PCs.

entries.name: Bonded in Loyalty
entries: Any of Valgred's allies that wear blue headbands count as thursir giants for her Call for Aid ability.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Valgred wears {@item hide armor|phb} (sized for a Large creature) and carries a {@item wand of binding}. Her {@item runic staff|ToB3-Lairs} is a magic quarterstaff that deals an additional {@damage 1d8} lightning damage on a hit once per short rest.
Two stone outhouses stand in a state of disrepair along the southern palisade with the wooden doors of both displaying indications of advanced rot.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One {@creature orc} wearing a blue headband is currently napping on the western side of the outhouses. The {@creature orc} has a passive {@skill Perception} of 10. If a battle takes place in {@area 6|15.6|u}, he wakes and joins after 1 round.

entries.name: 10. Converted Stables

entries: An expansive stone building with two solid wooden doors still stands strong despite the scars from the destructive attack in the past. The floor is covered in hay, and it's clear it was once a stable, but now it's been converted into a makeshift living space. A desk stands against the southern wall, and a worn wooden sits on the floor between a pair of bunk beds against the eastern wall.

This large stone building was used as a stable by the dwarves, but it's now being used as sleeping quarters by followers of Kadal. Once the occupants are dealt with, this room can be used by the PCs to safely have a short rest if the doors are barricaded.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature orc||orcs} and one {@creature orc veteran|ToB3-Lairs|veteran (orc)} are currently slumbering.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: For the {@creature veteran}, replace all mentions of "{@item longsword|phb}" with "{@item battleaxe|phb}" and "{@item shortsword|phb}" with "{@item handaxe|phb}."

entries.name: Entering the Room
entries: The {@creature orc||orcs} have a passive {@skill Perception} of 10; the {@creature orc veteran|ToB3-Lairs|orc veteran's} is 12. If a PC attempts to open the door quietly, their Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check is made with disadvantage due to the doors creaking loudly when they open. If the PCs just open the door without any concern for quietness, the guards awaken, but are surprised for the first round.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest contains a pouch of eight rubies (worth 200 gp total) and a silver chalice (worth 45 gp).

entries.name: 11. Lost Forge Entry

entries: The entrance of this towering stone building has two heavy stone doors etched with depictions of dwarven blacksmiths kneeling before the sky. Two stone statues flank the doorway. The statue on the left is an armored dwarf with a maul raised to the sky; the head of this statue has been crudely removed and lies on the ground nearby. The statue on the right has been partially melted by an intense source of heat.

The two statues once bore the likenesses of the dwarven deities of the forge; the one to the north was destroyed during the dragon attack long ago, and the one to the south has been defaced by the followers of the twin warlords. The double doors are currently shut, but not locked.

entries.name: 12. Chamber of Armor

entries: Unlike what you've seen elsewhere in the encampment, this chamber is spotless and kept in a state of impeccable repair. Eight stands holding armor forged of dark metal and adorned with skulls line the walls in rows as straight as the finest honed edge. There are no light sources in this darkened chamber, except for a glowing light—and oppressive heat—straight ahead coming from the forge. You also hear the ringing sounds of someone hammering on metal.
Kadal prefers a clean workplace and has his followers routinely clean the building to his standards.

entries.name: Forging in Progress
entries: When the PCs enter this area, Kadal is standing north of the forge, by the anvil (see {@area 15|15.15|u}), hammering out a {@item greatsword|phb} blade. He is initially just out of view, though the PCs can see the end of the anvil and the sparks flying off of it as the hammer comes down. Due to the hammering, it's possible Kadal won't notice the PCs until they get quite close.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The suits of armor lining the hall are 8 suits of {@item splint armor|phb|splint mail} adorned with skulls, forged by Kadal and sized for 9-foot-tall (Large) creatures; it weighs twice as much as regular {@item splint armor|phb|splint mail}.
This room contains a large bed piled with bear furs in the western corner. Two heavy iron chests stand against the northern wall.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The iron chests are filled with plunder from recent raids and require either a successful DC 18 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to break them open. One contains 1,100 gp and 4 bloodstone gems (worth 200 gp total). The other contains 175 cp, 1,700 sp, and 2 moonstones (worth 100 gp total).

This is a simple room occupied mostly by crates of copper ore. A stack of dusty blacksmithing molds and an impressive collection of blacksmithing tools clutter a sturdy workbench along the eastern wall.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: There are enough tools in this room to make three complete sets of {@item smith's tools|phb}. There are 7 crates of copper ore (worth 35 gp total), but each one is extremely heavy, weighing several hundred pounds each.

This large chamber with a vaulted ceiling is lit by the Lost Forge. A smelting area, a massive dark-iron anvil, and a huge worktable dominate much of the room. Atop the tables are immense blacksmithing tools that look as if made for the hands of giants.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Kadal, a {@creature thursir armorer|ToB3|thursir giant armorer}, is currently working angrily at the forge after a recent argument with his sister. As the PCs approach, four small creatures emerge from the forge—these four {@creature magma mephit||magma mephits} follow Kadal and aid him with his work. Kadal stops working when he discovers intruders in the forge and immediately grabs his {@item battleaxe|phb} and {@item shield|phb} to deal with them.

entries.name: Power of the Lost Forge
entries: The magical forge emits an aura in the chamber that powers the heating of metal, which effects the {@creature magma mephit||magma mephits} by replacing their Innate Spellcasting ability from (1/Day) to {@recharge 5}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Kadal's {@item battleaxe|phb} and {@item shield|phb}, which he crafted himself, are a {@item vicious battleaxe||vicious axe} and a {@item +1 shield}. His armor is non-magical, but crafted with his expert smithing hand.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: With the twin warlords defeated, any remaining followers flee into the mountains to find other employment. If Ruby Runemaker survives being prisoner, she offers a favor to the PCs if they should ever need it, along with a barrel of their finest dwarven ale, as thanks. The local villages see the PCs as their saviors, and they are offered free lodging and meals whenever they travel through.

After seeing that the magic of The Lost Forge has been rekindled, Ruby Runemaker brings word to her people, and the dwarves begin the process of rebuilding the walls to once again use the forge for making armor and weapons for the defense of the surrounding lands.
The thursir giant conclave where the twins came from hear of their defeat will someday come seeking vengeance for their fallen kin.

data.name: The Monstrous Machinations of Margrave Millard

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 7th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: Margrave Millard always had a fascination with monsters, even as a child. This was a harmless fascination until he inherited his estate and met Researcher Voss. The pair shared an interest, and while Millard loved the power and primal strength of monstrosities, Voss loved the act of creation, idolizing the wizards who created creatures like the {@creature owlbear}. The two believed each was capable of achieving their goals—that Voss would create great and terrible creatures to unleash upon the world and that Millard would {@i become} one of the monsters he so idolized.

Eventually, the pair escalated from plotting and research to experimentation. Disfavored servants and travelers began to disappear, rare and exotic monsters were imported, and Millard's mansion was converted into a laboratory so that the pair might create their monsters and unleash them upon unwitting victims to see how effectively they fought. As they ran out of convenient victims, they began to branch out, kidnapping merchant caravans, passing mercenaries, and unruly peasants—flinging them into an arena with their newest creations.

This was bad enough, but in the last month things have escalated. Margrave Millard is close to a breakthrough. He just needs a worthy foe to test himself against. He has begun to act openly, simply storming villages and towns he is lord of and kidnapping dozens to test against himself and his beast. The people don't know what's happening, why their lord has begun to terrorize them, what he plans in his isolated manse, or what his ultimate goal is.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: This adventure can take place in any rural area, where news travels slowly and a powerful noble can get away with abusing his own populace. The PCs are hired in the small mining town of Iron Hill, where the local lord has been terrorizing his populace for months. Their contact is Jasmine, a local miner who has begged their urgent assistance saving the townsfolk from the local lord.

Jasmine is a respected mining forewoman (N human {@creature scout}) in Iron Hill. She has sun-damaged skin, the strong build of a miner, and has lived in Iron Hill her whole life. She's gruff, serious, and self-assured but knows that she's out of her league with regard to the margrave's recent rampage.

entries.name: The Job
entries: Margrave Millard has been kidnapping citizens for unknown experiments for weeks, and no one he's taken has emerged from his secluded manor. Jasmine wants the PCs to stop the experiments and kill Millard for his crimes.

entries.name: Reward
entries: 400 gp for each PC, as well as everything they can carry from the margrave's home.

entries.name: Additional Information
entries: Jasmine also shares the following:

items: Margrave Millard lives in an isolated manor in the center of the woods, only an hour's ride from Iron Hill.

Millard has always been an odd man with an obsession with magical creatures, but was largely considered an acceptably neglectful lord until the experiments started, as he'd ignore his subjects and occasionally forget to collect taxes.
Millard has at least a dozen servants—thugs of various sorts—and a trained owlbear.
Before the kidnappings started, a shipment of a dozen or more caged animals was delivered to his manor.

entries.name: Millard's Manse
entries: Millard's Manse is a squat, overgrown gothic manor surrounded by looming willows and covered in creeping vines. Jasmine's directions bring the PCs straight to it without incident.

entries.name: Doors
entries: In addition to a large front door, there are 15-foot-wide barndoors on the eastern and western sides of the house, toward the back of the building. Unless otherwise noted, all doors—including the front door—are wooden and unlocked. The barndoors are both barred from the inside, requiring a successful DC 18 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to break them open.

entries.name: Portcullis
entries: There are two heavy iron portcullis in {@area 5|16.5|u}. Each has AC 19, 27 hit points, and a damage threshold of 10, but the margrave gladly orders the gate opened if the PCs wish to enter the arena.

entries.name: Illumination
entries: The margrave has allowed his manse to fall into disrepair. Little light filters through barred windows and many rooms are lit only by sparse candles, providing dim light throughout the manse.

entries.name: Margrave Millard
entries: Margrave Millard (NE human {@creature druid}) is a tall, pale man in his early 30s. He dresses in baggy formalwear that hangs off his frame, giving him the impression of being far scrawnier than he actually is. He's always been obsessed with physical strength and the freedom and respect he believes it can provide. He also really likes to hear himself talk, which is the foundation of his friendship with the stubbornly quiet Researcher Voss (NE human {@creature priest}).

While Millard is well-educated and is keen to justify himself with philosophical diatribes about the fundamental meaninglessness of life and the purity of a natural life, he's utterly uninterested in what others have to say. Allies have their words interpreted as supporting him, and everyone else is casually dismissed as worthless.

Millard can speak to anyone in his manor, no matter what room they're in, via the enchanted pyramidal stone in {@area 9|16.9|u}; it's one-way communication only, so he can't hear any reply. The margrave uses the opportunity to monologue at his guests while they explore the manor. He can also see what his guests are doing, but only in {@area 1|16.1|u}, via the enchanted spectacles in {@area 9|16.9|u}.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/16.jpg}.}

This extravagant foyer may once have been luxurious, but now it's best described as eerie. Half the candles on the chandelier are unlit, casting the room in dim, unpleasant light, while the once-gleaming hardwood floors are now marred with overlapping scratch and claw marks. Two threadbare chairs (with their cushions missing) flank the entryway. Directly ahead there's a door to the north with a large, sneering face carved into the wall above it.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Margrave Millard watches the entrance hall, using a pair of enchanted spectacles (see {@area 9|16.9|u}) to look through the eyes of the sneering face above the door. When he spots the PCs, he introduces himself, his voice reverberating all around the PCs, as if coming from the house itself. He thanks them for volunteering as his final test subjects, then urges them to step through the door to the north, so that the demonstration can begin. He calls them cowards if they go through any other door.

This plain room hosts three bunks, each with a pair of small wooden chests at its foot. A polished wooden table sits in the center of the room, with several chairs and stools arranged around it. The room is better maintained than the rest of the manse—clean, comfortable, and free of damage.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature thug||thugs} and three {@creature veteran||veterans} are relaxing in this room. They are dedicated servants of the margrave and attack intruders, fighting to the death. However, if the margrave has died in the arena, they flee the manor.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Most of the chests contain mundane personal effects, but inside one is a {@item bag of holding} containing 15 human left ears and 2 lbs. of beef jerky.

This ostentatiously painted room hosts three bunks, each with a pair of small wooden chests at its foot. The floor has been covered in wolf pelts that have suffered the wear and tear of having many, many boots trod upon them. Standing in the center of the room is a set of table and chairs and in the northeast corner is a writing desk.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature thug}, two {@creature bandit captain||bandit captains}, and two {@creature veteran||veterans} are eating a meal in this room. They are dedicated servants of the margrave and attack intruders, fighting to the death. However, if the margrave has died in the arena, they flee the manor.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Most of the chests contain mundane personal effects, but one contains 1,500 sp and a note detailing payroll for the Manse's guards over the next month.

entries.name: 4. Small Creature Holding Pens

entries: This long, narrow room expands into a small alcove at its northern end, where you can see shreds of half-eaten flesh and fragments of bone scattered. Wooden cages are pressed against the walls here and wherever else there is space, and the area reeks of rotting meat and the acrid stench of a spilled alchemical reagents. This looks as if it might have once have been a kitchen, as you see a chimney and oven against the outer wall, next to it a water basin, and to the northeast a counter—now dedicated to what must be monster food—that may once have been used for food preparation. A barndoor on the western wall, which is barred on this side, appears to lead outside the manse.
Behind the northernmost door leading into {@area 5|16.5|u} is a heavy iron portcullis.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If they have not yet been released into the arena ({@area 5|16.5|u}), there are four {@creature capybear|ToB3|capybears}), four {@creature razorfeather raptor|ToB3|razorfeather raptors}, and an animal handler (a {@creature thug}) in this area. If the PCs are spotted, the thug orders the animals to attack.
If the creatures are in this area, add the following read aloud text:
Near one of the cages, an animal handler looks to be training—or perhaps just playing with—a feathered bipedal dinosaur taller than he is.

entries.name: Cages
entries: Several of the cages are more like dog crates—they're left open, and the creatures just have their own space that they can call their own. Both the {@creature capybear|ToB3|capybears} and {@creature razorfeather raptor|ToB3|raptors} are quite intelligent and loyal and have been well-trained.
Smaller crates have typical livestock—chickens and the like—for feeding the margrave's creatures.

This ballroom must once have been grand, its chandeliers glistening from mage-light, its polished floor made for dancing, the walls austere yet elegant with their marble decorations. Now, the marble is bloodstained, shattered furniture is scattered across the floor, and the stench of death suffuses the air. Heavy iron portcullis stand before the two northernmost doors on the east and west walls.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If the PCs entered from {@area 1|16.1|u}, the door behind them closes and magically locks after they enter (via the {@spell arcane lock} spell). The margrave thanks the PCs for entering his arena, then unleashes several waves of monstrosities upon them, grandiosely introducing each and explaining how it will tear them apart. The margrave grants the PCs two rounds of rest between attacks.
{@b First Wave:} Four {@creature capybear|ToB3|capybears} (from {@area 4|16.4|u}), one {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3} from {@area 7|16.7|u}.
{@b Second Wave:} Four {@creature razorfeather raptor|ToB3|razorfeather raptors} from {@area 4|16.4|u}.
{@b Third Wave:} Three {@creature grolar bear|ToB3|grolar bears} from {@area 7|16.7|u}.

{@b Final Wave:} Margrave Millard (NE human {@creature druid}) and Researcher Voss (NE human {@creature priest}) leave {@area 6|16.6|u} and one of them enters the arena through each portcullis. Upon arriving, the margrave gives the PCs an earnest congratulations, then announces the perfection of his experiments and transforms into a {@creature grolar bear alpha|ToB3}. He and Voss then attack; both fight to the death.

The {@creature thug||thugs} in {@area Areas 4|16.4|x} and {@area 7|16.7|x} lead the animals in their charge to the northern entrance of the arena, open the doors, then lift the portcullis and release Millard's beasts and monstrosities inside.
If the margrave is defeated, any of his remaining servants flee.

entries.name: 6. Observation Room

entries: The southern wall of this room is an enormous one-way mirror looking into the bloodstained arena. Arrayed before the mirror are a series of comfortable chairs with small tables between them, clearly seating for guests to watch whatever horrors are to be put on display. A door lies in the center of the northern wall; flanking it are a pair of tables that hold the accoutrement for drinks and hors-d'oeuvres. Towering portraits of sharp-faced men and women line the walls, and a one of the small tables has atop it several empty glasses that have not yet been cleared.
While the PCs fight in the arena, Millard and Voss watch them from these seats.
The mirror is magically protected by a persistent {@spell wall of force} effect.

entries.name: 7. Large Creature Holding Pens
entries: Behind the northernmost door leading into {@area 5|16.5|u} is a heavy iron portcullis. Three very large—and one enormous—animal cages occupy the northern end of this area.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If the creatures have not yet been released into the arena ({@area 5|16.5|u}), three {@creature grolar bear|ToB3|grolar bears}, a {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3}, and an animal handler (a {@creature thug}) are in this area. If the PCs are spotted, the handler orders the animals to attack.

An enormous cage with an ferocious-looking—and large—owlbear inside is pressed against the northern wall of this sprawling chamber, while three smaller—but still quite large—cages pushed against other walls contain some kind of snarling bear. An animal handler stands next to the southernmost bear cage and pets the creature through the bars.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: On her first turn, the handler opens the first {@creature grolar bear|ToB3|grolar bear's} cage, then rushes to the next and opens that one as well. On her next turn, she releases the {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3}. She then goes to release the final {@creature grolar bear|ToB3}, but the {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3}—perhaps enraged by the scent of blood in the air—turns on her, and kills her with a swipe of its mighty claws. The third {@creature grolar bear|ToB3} therefore remains caged. Before her untimely demise, upon releasing each of the beasts, the handler orders each one to attack.

If possible, the two {@creature grolar bear|ToB3|grolar bears} move to clog up the chokepoint in the hallway to allow the handler to release the {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3}; if she's killed by the PCs before she can release the {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3}, on its next turn it breaks free of its cage.
Tables and alchemical equipment and cauldrons fill this room. The sound of slowly roiling liquid is omnipresent, as is the acrid scent of strange reagents burning.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature slithy tove|ToB3|slithy toves} have finished gestating in one of the cauldrons. If the PCs start looting the laboratory, spend more than 1 minute inside, or discover the toves, the creatures crawl out of their cauldrons and attack.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In this room are two sets of {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, 4 pieces of fine glassware (worth 100 gp total) and 15 flasks of {@item alchemist's fire (flask)|phb|alchemist's fire}.

Bookcases line the walls of this chamber, and a formal table stands in the middle of the room with paperwork strewn across it. To the east and west of the table are a pair of comfortable-looking chairs, with smaller tables beside them, each of which hold a stack of books. On the central table is a strange, pyramidal stone engraved with runes, with a pair of large spectacles are chained to it.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If they were not defeated elsewhere, Margrave Millard (NE human {@creature druid}) and Researcher Voss (NE human {@creature priest}) wait in this room. Once the PCs are spotted, Millard turns into a {@creature grolar bear alpha|ToB3} and attacks.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: Researcher Voss casts {@spell spirit guardians} to protect themself and Millard and heals the margrave if he is reduced to fewer than 15 hit points. Margrave Millard loses all self-control when he transforms and attacks whatever PC is closest at any given time. Both fight to the death.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The spectacles allow the wearer to spend a bonus action to gaze through the eyes of the carving in {@area 1|16.1|u}. Any creature that speaks into the pyramidal stone broadcasts their voice to the entire manse. The bookshelves contain books on biology and monster ecology (worth 700 gp total to the right buyer). On the central table is a {@item spell scroll (4th level)||scroll} of {@spell polymorph} and a small box that contains 4 diamonds (worth 600 gp total).

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: The adventure concludes when the PCs bring an end to Margrave Millard's reign of terror.

If Millard or Voss are left alive, they say whatever they need to in order to convince the PCs that they'll cease their evil ways, but they absolutely will not. Neither is motivated by revenge and so are not likely to seek out the PCs again, but they could become a problem that the PCs have to deal with again in the future.

If both Millard and Voss are killed, but any of the creatures are left alive, the PCs must decide what do with them. The {@creature razorfeather raptor|ToB3} and {@creature dire owlbear|ToB3} are monstrosities too dangerous to release into the wild, thought the {@creature razorfeather raptor|ToB3|raptor} is intelligent enough (and has been around humans enough) that it's possible clever PCs—likely with the aid of magic—could convince the creatures to travel somewhere remote and not prey on sentient creatures. Under normal circumstances, the {@creature grolar bear|ToB3|grolar bears} and {@creature capybear|ToB3|capybears} could potentially be released into the wild, but the margrave has brought out the most vicious instincts in them and thus none are likely to make good neighbors.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 7th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: The halfling Zelen Barishka adventured during most of her early adulthood, growing in power as a druid as she traveled the world and fought monsters. Her true passion involved the study of plants, and she had occasion to note unusual species thriving in hidden locations or driven to near extinction because of the danger they posed to nearby settlements. She cataloged these plants' locations and vowed to return to retrieve, rescue, and study them.

When she retired, she used her accumulated wealth to build a hidden sanctuary where she could store and examine these notable plants. She also procured a strange golem capable of gathering and safely storing her prizes. Still afflicted with some wanderlust, Zelen also journeyed to recover plants herself. On her final trip, she fell to her death attempting to collect a cliff-dwelling shrub. Meanwhile, her golem assistant arrived from its latest assignment to obtain the fruit from a plant the halfling knows as an alaguara and now awaits Zelen's return so it can release its bounty.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i Botanist Check-in.}} One of Zelen's botanist colleagues has been expecting to receive an alaguara seed from the druid to assist in the plant's study, and its delivery is now considerably past due. The botanist offers the PCs a reward to travel to Zelen's sanctum to check in with her.

{@b {@i Fashioning a Cure.}} The PCs may require the alaguara plant held by the golem to fashion a cure for a disease or other malady afflicting one of their number, an important NPC, or an entire settlement.

entries.name: The Green Sanctum

entries: Ahead, the trees thin, providing better access to the river flowing through the forest and revealing a stone structure nestled on an island about thirty feet from the bank. Two clear glass domes top the vine-covered building.

Granite forms the basis of the island supporting the stone building, allowing Zelen to comfortably commission the material used for the building's construction without fear of it sinking. Narrow slits in the walls allow ample light to penetrate the building while keeping out all but the smallest creatures. During the day, bright light fills the building except where noted, but, at night, darkness engulfs the building, as there are no continuous light sources. Contrasting with the stone walls, wooden doors allow access to the sanctum's inner chambers.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Twelve {@creature dust mephit||dust mephits} serve Zelen by carrying out mundane tasks and warding off intruders while she is away. When the PCs enter any room except {@area 16|17.16|u}, they have a chance to encounter the creatures. Roll a {@dice d10}; on a roll of 1, they encounter two {@creature dust mephit||mephits}, or on a roll of 2–4, they encounter one. Each {@creature dust mephit} can use its action to activate the entangling roots growing beneath the sanctum. These roots can only be activated once per day in each area and reset at dawn.

entries.name: Entangling Roots
entries: Thanks to the druid's coaxing, dozens of roots grow from the riverbed and symbiotically intertwine with the granite to create one of the sanctum's defense measures. Roots snake through holes in the floor in a 15-foot radius centered on a designated point for 1 minute. For the duration, that area is treated as difficult terrain for creatures other than plants. In addition, each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 12 Strength saving throw or become {@condition restrained}. A creature can use its action to make a DC 12 Strength check, freeing itself or another entangled creature within reach on a success.

entries.name: Fire Suppression System
entries: Another magical defense system counters the threat fire poses to the sanctum's rare specimens. After a creature uses magic or an effect that deals fire damage, the sanctum—as if it were a creature using its reaction—douses any fire caused by the effect, and the creature responsible, using the following attack:

entries.name: Freezing Spray
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit +4} to hit, one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage and douses any nonmagical flames on the target.

The fire suppression system can also target an ongoing spell that deals fire damage, such as {@spell flaming sphere}, as if it cast {@spell dispel magic} ({@d20 +4} bonus on the ability check). The sanctum gets its reaction back on initiative count 20.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/17.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Beach Landing

entries: The wide river separating the banks from this modest island in its center proves easy to navigate. Thorny grasses cover much of the sandy soil surrounding the building.

The island stands 30 feet from the nearest bank and the water reaches a maximum depth of 15 feet halfway between the bank and the island. Near the island, the depth varies from 5 to 7 feet. Zelen left the native grasses alone apart from those she cleared prior to the sanctum's construction.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature vine-covered owlbear|ToB3-Lairs|vine-covered owlbears}, trained and altered by Zelen, patrol the beach. Without hearing the proper series of whistles known only to the druid, the {@creature vine-covered owlbear|ToB3-Lairs|owlbears} attack any creatures that set foot on the beach. They do not pursue creatures that move more than 10 feet from the beach.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: Once per short or long rest, the {@creature owlbear||owlbears} can use their action to produce an effect similar to the {@spell entangle} spell (spell save DC 13). It has a range of only 20 feet, but requires no concentration. The vines covering the creatures shoot out to the point within range to create the effect.

entries.name: 2. Sanctum Entrance

entries: As you enter the sanctum, you see a long hallway stretching ahead north; in the immediate vicinity, to the east and west are closed wooden doors. The flooring is cool to the touch and looks to be natural stone, polished mostly smooth.

If the PCs arrive during the day, the light that shines through the dome in {@area 6|17.6|u} provides enough illumination through the Observation Pane ({@area 3|17.3|u}) to be notable even from the entrance.
The hallway ends at a large, frigid, ice-rimed glass pane through which one can view the plants contained within a glass dome. At the southern end of the hall, closed doors lead to the east and west.

entries.name: Glass Pane
entries: The glass pane has AC 15, 30 hit points, a damage threshold of 10, and immunity to piercing, slashing, poison, and psychic damage. Destroying the pane attracts the attention of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature dust mephit||dust mephits}, which arrive in 2 rounds to attack the offenders.

entries.name: 4. Zelen's Living Quarters

entries: This spare living space contains a neatly made bed, a small wooden table with numerous ring stains from mugs and tankards, a writing desk with an open leather-bound book, and a wardrobe.

The desk is clear of items except for Zelen's journal open to its final entry, dated three weeks ago; the entry reads: "I've sent my assistant to find one of the last known specimens of the alaguara, which has faced eradication from people unkindly disposed to its invasive qualities. While he is out on his mission, I shall undertake my own quest to retrieve a rare flowering plant that climbs the Blackrock Cliffs." The journal spans a month prior to the last date and features discussions about a species of orchid that spits poisonous thorns and a plan to seek out the flower later.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A set of {@item goggles of night} hang from a hook behind a heavy cloak in the wardrobe.

entries.name: 5. Plant-Lined Hallway

entries: Numerous flowering shrubs and bushes thrive in this hallway and fill it with sweet fragrances. The temperature drops significantly as the hallway proceeds north.
As the corridor turns east, a set of double doors on the eastern wall stand open (to {@area 6|17.6|u}); opposite that, on the western wall, is a closed single door (to {@area 7|17.7|u}).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature alpine creeper|ToB3|alpine creepers}, which typically dwell in the arctic sanctum, lurk in the colder northern section of this hall, just south of the doors leading to {@area 6|17.6|u}. The plants ignore the {@creature dust mephit||dust mephits}, but they attack anyone else, fighting to the death.

entries.name: 6. Arctic Sanctum

entries: A blast of cold hits you as you enter this room. Ice coats most of this domed, circular room's surfaces, but the plants within clearly thrive here. The frost on the dome above dims the light shining through it.

Permanent magic keeps this chamber's temperature at just below the freezing point. A successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 17) ends the magic; if dispelled, the room warms to match the ambient temperature after four hours, causing most of the plants located here to wither and die.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: An {@creature ice willow|ToB3} stands along the room's southeastern arc. It waits until prey draws close enough for it to unleash its spray of ice shards with greatest effect. The willow fights until reduced to 20 hit points, at which point it attempts to retreat as far as it can within {@area 6|17.6|u} and cowers, saying in {@language Sylvan} "was scared", "no kill" or the like. If the PCs seem determined to kill it, however, it continues fighting to the death.

Gardening tools—trowels, shovels, rakes, and the like—haphazardly fill this shed and clutter the workbench along the northwestern wall. Though disorganized and well-used, the tools show no sign of disrepair and are free of dirt and rust.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check finds 4 flasks packed away under the workbench. Two of the flasks contain {@item plant eradicator|ToB3-Lairs} and two contain {@item plant revivifier|ToB3-Lairs}.

entries.name: 8. Tucked-Away Shrine

entries: The corridor ends at a wall ahead, at the foot of which is a shrine enshrouded in ferns and flowers.
The shrine is anointed to various nature deities to whom Zelen gave prayers while she adventured.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check discovers a faint crack in the wall, revealing a door that pushes inward to {@area 15|17.15|u}.

entries.name: 9. Vine-Covered Trellises

entries: Wooden frames covered with climbers line the north and south walls of this short hallway.
The vines react to vibrations, including footsteps, by shuddering in response, though they pose no danger.

entries.name: 10. Meeting Room

entries: A grand oak table surrounded by mahogany chairs fills most of this square chamber.

A single sheet of paper as well as a cup that once contained coffee are on the table; the paper seems to be notes from a meeting, from one druid to another. The room is empty apart from the table and chairs.

entries.name: 11. Moss-Coated Hallway

entries: Different strains of moss and lichen fill every inch of this hallway, including the ceiling and floor, deadening sound within it. The plants glow with blue and green iridescence when blocked from sunlight.
These plants are all just common mosses and lichen.
A riot of fungi covers a table along the southern wall of this lightless chamber. Shelf fungus covers most of the northern wall.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature shrieker} lurks among the other fungus here. If it raises its alarm, it draws {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature dust mephit||dust mephits} to the chamber 1 round later.

entries.name: 13. Storage Room

entries: Neatly stacked piles of books and papers cover the floor.
The material in this chamber contains mundane details about nature and plants.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check detects the seams of the door.

entries.name: 14. Research Vault

entries: The secret door opens to reveal a dark, cool chamber. Against the north wall stands a table, against the west wall a bookcase. Numerous tomes fill the bookshelf, and the desk has an array of journals and papers arrayed across it.
Zelen stored important correspondence, research tomes, and her own journal in this secret room.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Zelen's journals contain an array of information useful for those who study plants (worth 150 gp total to the right buyer). A creature who spends a month studying the research gains proficiency in Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) checks; if they are already proficient, their proficiency bonus is doubled for any Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check.

The journals also contain instructions for operating the {@creature ice golem|ToB3} in {@area 16|17.16|u}, including the command words necessary to activate and deactivate the construct. A PC can locate that information without spending days reading through all of the journals with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation} or {@skill Nature}) check; a {@class druid} makes this check with advantage.

This oddly shaped chamber holds a handful of tables laden with beakers, mortars and pestles, and tools used for the fine manipulation of herbs and reagents. A door provides the only entryway to a circular chamber contained within this laboratory.

entries.name: Lab Purpose
entries: If a PC spends 10 minutes or more examining the notes and equipment in the lab, with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation} or {@skill Nature}) check, they determine that Zelen used this lab to study harmful and dangerous plants to make them more harmonious with their surroundings, including the alaguara fruit. She wished to preserve its healing properties in a hybrid that wouldn't wipe out competing plants.

entries.name: Locked and Trapped Door
entries: A successful DC 15 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb} picks the lock. Electricity charges the door when opened and every creature within 10 feet of the door must make a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) lightning damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Prevention
entries: A successful DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check while inspecting the door finds nearly imperceptible runes carved in the wood. A spell or other effect that can sense the presence of magic, such as {@spell detect magic}, reveals an aura of evocation magic on the door. A successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 14) cast on the door deactivates the trap. The trap can be disarmed with a successful DC 17 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Failing this check by 5 or more discharges the trap and causes the PC to have disadvantage on the resulting saving throw.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Three {@item herbalism kit|phb|herbalism kits} can be collected from the equipment on the various tables. There are also 3 {@item potion of healing||potions of healing} and a {@item potion of greater healing}.
This domed chamber houses several strange trees and flowering plants, some of which seemingly move independently. A metal humanoid standing along the eastern wall seems incongruous to the greenery.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature shambling mound} guards this sanctum and attacks anyone other than Zelen who enters, fighting to the death.

Zelen's {@creature ice golem|ToB3} stands beside the eastern wall. It seeks only to protect the plant within its chest cavity, so it only attacks any creatures that move within its reach, targets it with ranged attacks, or uses spells or effects targeting it. If the proper command words found in Zelen's journals in {@area 14|17.14|u} are spoken, they deactivate the {@creature ice golem|ToB3|golem} and command it to release the alaguara fruit held in its chest cavity.

Attempting to forcibly remove the alaguara fruit causes the {@creature ice golem|ToB3|golem} to go berserk. In this state, the {@creature ice golem|ToB3|golem} attacks the nearest creature it can see, excluding the {@creature shambling mound}, even pursuing targets outside this area. It remains in this state until it is destroyed or deactivated.

If the PCs successfully navigate the {@creature ice golem|ToB3} without having to fight it, but you would like there to be more of a challenge to this final encounter, you can add additional {@filter plant creatures|bestiary|type=plant} to this combat—of which there are nearly {@filter two dozen in {@i Tome of Beasts 3}|bestiary|source=ToB3|type=plant}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The {@creature ice golem|ToB3} holds the alaguara fruit in stasis inside its chest cavity. There are no other objects of value in this room, but the plants growing here are almost all extremely rare or unique specimens of considerable value to those searching for or studying such plants.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: If the PCs retrieve the alaguara fruit, they receive a reward commensurate with the adventure hook you chose.
Another druid or scholar with an interest in Zelen's studies may eventually take up residence in the Green Sanctum and contact the PCs to share information about the location's denizens and traps.
If the PCs retrieved Zelen's journals, interested groups may contact them and ask about obtaining the journals and their secrets for a price.
The PCs may also receive a request to find Zelen's remains so she can receive a proper burial.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 8th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: The fur trader {@i Whippet} has been lost, presumably due to a non-functioning lighthouse and the foggy shoals outside of Wrackwater Cove (see {@adventure "Incident at Wrackwater"|ToB3-Lairs|14} adventure for additional background). Wrackwater locals have recently found confirmation of a nearby wreck location. Undoubtedly, it's {@i Whippet}, but the ship's investors and underwriters must have incontrovertible proof. They're also eager to recover some specific items that will confirm, document, and perhaps mitigate their financial losses.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: There have been many strange occurrences in the region recently, including the appearance of strange, dangerous creatures, and now the merchant schooner {@i Whippet}, which didn't arrive in port when expected, is no longer merely "overdue" but officially "lost at sea."

The Wrackwater town council, with funding provided by a group of maritime investors and guarantors, are looking for the assistance of "heroes" to recover the lost vessel. Given other recent events, it's entirely too dangerous for a mere salvage crew (though they tried and no one could be convinced to take the job), clearly a job for heroes.
The following hooks can used to start the PCs on this adventure. The PCs:

items: Already helped Wrackwater in the {@adventure "Incident at Wrackwater"|ToB3-Lairs|14} adventure and are recruited by their contacts from that previous adventure.
Are asked by one of their allies or patrons—who has a friend, relative, or colleague among the investors and/or town council—to travel to Wrackwater to investigate the strange goings-on there.
Are traveling in the vicinity and hear of the plight of the people of Wrackwater.

entries.name: The Job
entries: The investors wish to discuss enlisting the PCs for ship identity confirmation (by retrieving the ship's bell), insurance assessment (by retrieving the ship's manifest), and to report any other salvage opportunities at the recently confirmed wreck site. The town council is naturally most concerned with the PCs putting an end to the threat posed by the strange creatures that have been lurking about of late, but the investors are footing the bill and so their concerns are at the forefront of the negotiations.

If the PCs agree, the guarantors propose a total payment of 2,000 gp for the job. With the generous funding of the guarantors, the council offers transportation to and from the wreck site, with necessary diving and salvage equipment provided.

entries.name: The Good Barge Barnacle
entries: The PCs are brought to the wide, flat deck of the salvage barge Barnacle. This tattered barge sports a small pilot house, tool racks and cargo nets, and a small winch and a 150-foot boom. The PCs are greeted by Old Wil, {@i Barnacle's} master and commander, and then are introduced to his crew: Daisy (a geriatric parrot) and Dog (a pet harbor seal).

Wil cheerfully sets a crate down in front of the PCs and says, "The fine folk of the town council says for me to pass this along to ye heroes, so I'm'a doin' it." Inside the crate is a {@item sealskin coldsuit|ToB3-Lairs} (which grants the wearer a swimming speed of 20 feet), 3 {@item glowmold globe|ToB3-Lairs|glowmold globes}, and a {@item crowbar|phb}. Wil says he'll wait topside with "emergency refreshments and moral support."

entries.name: Some Nautical Terminology
entries: {@b Fore:} The front (bow) of the ship
{@b Aft:} The back (stern) of the ship
{@b Starboard:} The right side of the ship if facing the bow
{@b Port:} The left side of the ship if facing the bow
{@b Deck:} Floor; also used to refer to the levels of the ship—i.e., Deck 1, Deck 2, Upper Deck, etc.
{@b Overhead:} Ceiling
{@b Bulkhead:} Wall
{@b Bilge:} The lowest inner part of a ship, designed to collect excess water
{@b Binnacle:} A pedestal mounted at the helm that houses the ship's compass, made of wood and brass
{@b Capstan:} A type of large winch used to help the crew lift heavy weights and/or wind the ship's anchor
{@b Fo'c's'le:} Forecastle, the forward (main) deck of the ship (pronounced "FOKH-sil")
{@b Gangway Ladder:} Steep, ladder-like stairs
{@b Ship's Boat:} A smaller boat (typically a {@item rowboat}) carried by a larger vessel, used to communicate with shore or perform other tasks the larger ship may be otherwise incapable of

entries.name: The Wreck of the Whippet

entries: You descend more than seventy feet, diving down through water that seems uncharacteristically warm, with a clear current that feels like it zigzags through these waters. Before long, the capsized vessel comes into view and you see a jagged, wide hull breach that exposes the expansive darkness of the ship's bilge.
The PCs may free-dive or can be lowered down to the wreck via Barnacle's boom winch.

entries.name: Capsized Vessel
entries: Since the ship is upside-down, any "floor" (called "deck" on ships) the map depicts is actually ceiling (called "overhead"). Likewise, all descriptions referring to "the deck" mean the surface above and "the overhead" refers to the surface below.

entries.name: No Bodies
entries: The shipwreck is curiously devoid of dead crew, except for {@area Areas 12|18.12|x}–{@area 14|18.14|x}. {@i Whippet} had a crew of 16.

entries.name: Hatches and Doors
entries: While opening a hatch or door on a normal ship would be a free action, opening them underwater requires an action. Any Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check while opening a door or hatch is made with disadvantage due to the disturbance it causes in the water.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/18.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Bilge Breach
entries: The hull breach is 10 feet long and ranges from 1 foot to 3 feet wide, large enough for Small and Medium creatures to squeeze through without too much effort. Looking inside, the bilge is 4 feet high and crisscrossed with ribbing, ship beams, and shoring. The bilge access hatch to/from the cargo hold ({@area 3|18.3|u}) hangs open 15 feet aft of this hull breach.

entries.name: 2. Forward Hull Breach
entries: A large breach pierces the hull here near the bottom of the bow; it's 2 feet by 7 feet and opens into {@area 5|18.5|u}. Inside, a vast amount of cargo is haphazardly piled up on Deck 2 as far as the eye can see.

entries.name: Deck 2: Dire Depths
entries: As a reminder, Deck 2 actually rests below the bilges and above Deck 1 due to the {@i Whippet} being inverted.
Huge piles of ruined goods and freight crowd the hold's aft end, some of which stretch nearly all the way from the overhead to the deck above.

entries.name: Hatch
entries: A portside hatch in the deck above leads to the bilge ({@area 1|18.1|u}).

entries.name: Vision
entries: The towers of cargo here may impede a creature's line of sight and/or cover options.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature dire lionfish|ToB3} lurk here in the shadows, making their home here as if the piles of cargo were coral. The pair are viciously territorial and have claimed the entirety of Deck 2 as their domain. Unless the PCs succeed on a DC 19 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check, the {@creature dire lionfish|ToB3} detect the PCs approaching and attempt to ambush them when they come within 15 feet. They fight to the death to protect their territory.

Once combat ensues, there is a {@chance 60|60%} chance of attracting {@dice 1d4 + 1} curious {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} from {@area 9|18.9|u} who come through the cargo hatch (that connects {@area 9|18.9|u} to {@area 4|18.4|u}) and join the fray. (The chance increases to 100% if the PCs use a cacophonous effect like the spell {@spell thunderwave}.) The curious {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|gremlins} arrive after 2 rounds and happily attack both the {@creature dire lionfish|ToB3|lionfish} and the PCs.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the PCs wish, they can harvest the {@item dire lionfish spine|ToB3-Lairs|dire lionfish spines} with a successful DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check; on a failure of 5 or more, the PC attempting the task takes {@damage 2d6} poison damage. 30 spines are available to collect; the PC must repeat the check every 10 spines they harvest, and the process of removing them takes 5 minutes of excruciating, cautious work. If another PC wishes to help, the Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check can be made with advantage, but the helping PC must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or suffer {@damage 2d6} poison damage.

entries.name: Bilge Gremlin Tactics
entries: {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|Bilge gremlins} (and {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3|bosuns}) are wily and slippery foes. They rely on their evasiveness to be effective, and so they take full advantage of {@footnote their ability to cast {@spell misty step} at will|Neither {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} nor {@creature bilge gremlin bosuns|ToB3|bosuns} can do this.}, rarely ending a turn adjacent to an enemy if at all possible. Likewise, whenever they detect danger, they make frequent use of {@footnote their at-will {@spell invisibility}|Neither {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} nor {@creature bilge gremlin bosuns|ToB3|bosuns} can do this.} to spring ambushes.

entries.name: 4. Main Cargo Hold, Forward

entries: This area is mostly clear of cargo and detritus, though the mainmast bears a deep indentation as if something forcefully slammed into it. Amidship, you can see the outline of the cargo hatch in the overhead that goes to the next deck. A gaping hull breach in the starboard bow is visible from here.
The {@creature dire lionfish|ToB3} in {@area 3|18.3|u} headbutted the mast as part of claiming its territory and/or letting out some aggression.

entries.name: Hatch
entries: The cargo hatch in the overhead (the floor, since the ship is upside-down) leads from Area 4 to {@area 9|18.9|u}.

Several crates and barrels are strewn about this area, the wood on several of them shattered, spilling their contents. Some bits of grain float in the water here, remnants, perhaps, of one of these broken barrels or sacks, the rest already washed out to sea.

entries.name: Hatch
entries: A portside gangway ladder (staircase) leads to a hatch that opens onto Deck 1.

entries.name: Breach
entries: A hull breach (see {@area 2|18.2|u}) is located on the starboard bow here. On the edge of the breach, a large spine protrudes from the bulkhead (from the {@creature dire lionfish|ToB3} in {@area 3|18.3|u}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The {@item dire lionfish spine|ToB3-Lairs} can be collected and used as a weapon.

entries.name: Deck 1: Battle of the Bilgies
entries: Nine {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} and a {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3} have taken ownership of {@area Areas 6|18.6|x}–{@area 9|18.9|x}. If combat ensues in any of those locations, the gremlins call out to each other and then converge and attack as a group.

Suspended from the capstan on the deck are great lengths of four-inch-thick rope dangling in the seawater and coiling in tangled snarls below. Yards and yards of tangled mooring and anchor lines likewise litter the overhead.

entries.name: Hatch
entries: A portside gangway ladder (staircase) leads to a hatch that opens onto the fo'c's'le, the forward part of the main deck.

entries.name: Rope
entries: Due to being extremely waterlogged, these hemp ropes are not floating freely as they would otherwise.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} are napping in this room, hidden amongst the ropes. They wake when the hatch or door is opened, unless the creature opening the door or hatch succeeds on a DC 12 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check. If the PCs enter the room undetected, it requires a successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to notice the {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|gremlins}.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: If the gremlins are alerted to the PCs' entrance, {@footnote they cast {@spell invisibility} on themselves|{@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|Bilge gremlins} can't do this.} and wait for the PCs to enter the hallway; once inside, they sing out to their comrades in {@area Areas 7|18.7|x}, {@area 8|18.7|x}, and {@area 9|18.9|x}.

entries.name: 7–8. Forward Crew Quarters

entries: Hammocks and tie-downs float like ghosts between ship beams, articles of clothing bedding and common sailor's effects drift about the flooded compartment.
Both of these rooms are identical crew quarters for 6 individuals.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: One {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3} sleeps in each of these rooms. If any combat ensues anywhere in {@area Areas 6|18.6|x}–{@area 9|18.9|x}, they awaken and join the fray.
This cargo hold is in as dismal condition as you might expect. All manner of cargo has been cast about, making the space a chaotic mess.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} are scavenging in this cluttered, warehouse-like space. The gremlins converge on the PCs once they become aware of them. If the PCs open the hatch above, {@footnote the gremlins all cast {@spell invisibility} on themselves|{@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|Bilge gremlins} can't do this.}.

In the southwest corner, a large bell lies on its side with the top of a crate leaning against its mouth. Once the PCs are detected, a {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3} comes out of the bell that he has claimed as his home.

entries.name: Locked Door
entries: The door leading to {@area 10|18.10|u} is locked, but can be picked with a successful DC 12 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Inside the ship's bell is a bottle of vintage brandy (worth 150 gp), a sextant, a leather pouch containing several (human) finger bones, and a brass cabin key (which opens the door to {@area 10|18.10|u}).

entries.name: The Ship's Bell
entries: The {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3|bosun's} "home" is the {@i Whippet's} ship's bell. Made out of solid bronze, it's 18 inches tall, with a mouth diameter of 20 inches. Salvaging the bell, which weighs 225 lbs., requires {@i Barnacle's} boom winch, clever planning and teamwork, and/or magic.

entries.name: Deck 1: Wrath of the Wrackwraiths
entries: In {@area Areas 12|18.12|x}–{@area 14|18.14|x} lurk five {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths}. If combat ensues in any of those areas, all of the {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths} converge and attack as a group.
When the PCs first encounter one of the {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths}, read or paraphrase the following:

Out of the corner of your eye, you detect motion, and you turn to see, rising in the water, a humanoid shape formed by torn fabric and sundered wood, shorn hair and shattered bone. Then you hear a sound, almost as if from inside your own head—a sound reminiscent of the last gasp of a person drowning.

entries.name: Beach Bound
entries: The "beach" these {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths} are bound to is the seafloor upon which the {@i Whippet} wrecked. Their spirits are unable to leave the ship, where the callous {@creature bilge gremlin|ToB3|bilge gremlins} that caused the wreck laughed as they watched them drown. The {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths} won't enter {@area 9|18.9|u} or beyond.

entries.name: 10–11. Galley & Kitchen

entries: This area was clearly the ship's galley. Chairs, cutlery, and dishes are scattered about; the tables the crew ate at hanging above you, attached to the deck. Through the open door to port, you can see a smaller room that is clearly the galley's kitchen.
Inside the galley and the kitchen, the PCs find about what you'd expect in such places, nothing more.

entries.name: 12–13. Passenger Staterooms

entries: This cabin was once nicely appointed, seemingly for passengers. Naturally, now it's a total ruin. A bloated corpse floats in one of the corners.
Both of these rooms are essentially identical quarters for 1–2 individuals.

entries.name: Door Ajar
entries: The door to this room is ajar.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Each room contains one {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: One of the corpses—a woman wearing a fashionable dress—is wearing an onyx ring (worth 90 gp) bearing the inscription "Wrackwater 5 Annual Springfair Queen."

entries.name: 14. Aft Crew Quarters

entries: This room was clearly once used as crew quarters; you can see the torn remnants of numerous hammocks and destroyed footlockers, as well as clothes and other personal effects. Now, however, the room is clearly used for storing bodies. The bloated, floating corpses of the entire crew seem to have been shoved into this room, with no respect for the dead, or any sense of propriety whatsoever. But the crew aren't the only dead present: Floating nearby are three dead gremlins.
There were once nine hammocks hanging in these quarters. Now most of them are on the ground . . . or being used for nefarious purposes by the current occupants.

entries.name: Door Ajar
entries: The door to this room is ajar.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature wrackwraith|ToB3|wrackwraiths} lurk in this room.

entries.name: Dead Gremlins
entries: The {@creature bilge gremlin bosun|ToB3|bosun} in {@area 9|18.9|u} ordered this area off-limits after the three gremlins were killed. If any living gremlins are questioned, they don't know what's in Area 14, but they know they don't want to mess with it after Scobbe, Votrag, and Blarck didn't come back.

entries.name: Bodies
entries: Further inspection of the area reveals that all of the crew's fingers have been severed and are missing.

entries.name: Upper Deck
entries: As a reminder, the "upper" deck is actually the lowest level of the {@i Whippet}, due to it being inverted.

entries.name: 15. Bosun's Hatch
entries: A hatch on the deck opens from Area 15 to {@area 6|18.6|u}. A portside gangway ladder (staircase) is on the other side of the hatch.

Looking up, you can see the main deck above you, along with half of the splintered mainmast—the other half sundered on the seafloor. Broken gear, tangled rigging, and shattered spars and yards are littered about this area. In the center of the deck above, you can see a closed cargo hatch. Among the debris on the seafloor, the overturned ship's boat lies capsized, partially embedded in the sand. Of more immediate concern, however, are the figures before you. Festooned in nudibranchs, starfish, and anemones, an amphibious troll leads two large, clawed and finned humanoid creatures with merfolk-like tails toward the sterncastle.

entries.name: Ship's Boat
entries: The ship's boat is approximately 12 feet by 8 feet; large enough to carry six Medium-sized creatures

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature breakwater troll|ToB3} leads two {@creature merrow} toward the sterncastle ({@area 18|18.18|u}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In the ship's boat is an airtight flask containing 2 doses of a {@item potion of superior healing}.

Lengths of anchor shanks and chain lie on the seafloor nearby a barrel of harpoons lying on its side. Portside, the ship's binnacle—a wooden and brass pedestal about three-and-a-half feet tall—protrudes from the seabed, partially embedded in the sand, its brass and glass dome cracked and filled with water. Aftward, you see the inverted sterncastle, a large cabin that stands atop the aft end of the deck.

entries.name: The Compass Array
entries: The binnacle contains the ship's compass array. Salvaging the compass array, which weighs 275 lbs., requires {@i Barnacle's} boom winch, clever planning and teamwork, and/or magic.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The PCs can also collect 8 harpoons (use statistics for {@item spear|phb}).
