Rainbow-hued colonies of anemones, sponges, and starfish drape the glistening walls and carpet the deck and overhead in this room that was once the captain's quarters. A grotesque humanoid figure floating in the center of the room—with blue, bloated, dead-looking skin, and hair resembling kelp—looks up at you as you enter. From the north, another figure comes around the half-wall, draped in seaweed and slime, encrusted with barnacles. This one is also humanoid, but has scaled skin and eel-like tail instead of legs. On her face is a terrifying smile, which falters into a momentary look of confusion upon seeing you, before recovering. "You are not who I was expecting. But welcome," she says, moving toward you and gesturing for you to enter. "Come in, come in."

entries.name: Magical Wards
entries: Area 18 can't be scryed upon, teleported into, or otherwise breached by any means short of a {@spell wish} spell. Only Mother Celeste can negate/bypass this effect.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Mother Celeste, a {@creature brine hag|ToB3} and a {@creature sea hag}, attack once the PCs enter.

entries.name: Magic Chest
entries: Against the aft wall is a magically locked chest (via the {@spell arcane lock} spell); it can be unlocked with Mother Celeste's key or picked with a successful DC 30 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Any inanimate object inside the chest is immune to the effects of water; if the object has been stored in the chest for at least 4 hours, if it is removed, it maintains this immunity for 24 hours. Both it, and the key (which Mother Celeste carries) radiate abjuration magic if {@spell detect magic} is cast.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Mother Celeste wears an {@item amulet of proof against detection and location} and, also around her neck, is a key on a chain.

Inside the chest: There is 308 sp, 221 gp; 4 {@item spell scroll (3rd level)||scrolls} of {@spell sending}; the {@i Whippet's} ship's manifest; the ship's log, which contains sketches depicting a number of sunken shipwrecks arranged around {@i Whippet} in such a way that makes it very closely resemble an underwater fortress; stacks of current nautical charts, including local tidal tables and vessel names—and their sizes and shipping schedules.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: Returning topside safely, the PCs find Old Wil there waiting for them, as promised—with the promised refreshments. With the Barnacle's winch and Old Wil's know-how, it's a simple enough matter to recover the heavy salvage items.

If the PCs retrieve the ship's manifest and the ship's bell, they receive the agreed upon reward and the eternal thanks of the guarantors and investors. If the PCs also salvage anything else valuable from the wreck other than the manifest and bell, at GM discretion, the guarantors offer an additional reward for items such as the ship's compass and/or log.

If the PCs also put an end to the threat of Mother Celeste and her coterie, the town council is even more grateful, dubbing them "The Heroes of Wrackwater" and insisting on throwing a feast in their honor.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 8th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: Centuries ago, the {@creature red greatwyrm|FTD|great wyrm red dragon} Soriantathalga laired in the heart of Mount Sagur. Mount Sagur was one of two small, adjacent "twin" volcanos at the edge of a large mountain range near the coast, the other being Mount Magra. Adventurers slew the dragon in a cataclysmic battle, which caused Sagur to erupt, killing them and everything else for miles.
A small caldera formed where Mount Sagur had been. Only about 100 feet in diameter, it has been little more than a blasted pit for centuries; meanwhile, Mount Magra has remained dormant.

In the aftermath of the cataclysm, the plains to the west of Mount Magra and the Sagur caldera became incredibly fertile. Over time, plants grew again in the ground and people settled there, founding villages and cultivating farmland. The closest village is Dorma, about 5 miles away, situated on a burbling stream fed by mountain springs.

Over the course of the last week, several farmers in the area heard strange sounds coming from the caldera—and others reported sightings of monsters, though none of the creatures attacked or approached any of the farms.

Upon learning of this, Ferriahn Colvane—a cleric of Volund, god of earth and fire—went to investigate. She inspected the caldera and its surroundings, finding no sign of volcanic activity in the caldera or Mount Magra, nor did she find any creatures, though she did find some scorched trees. Unsatisfied but out of leads, Ferriahn returned to the village to research and await further developments. After hearing more of the same from the farmers, she returned to investigate again only to discover that the caldera was bubbling with magma and Mount Magra was leaking toxic volcanic gas. Using her magic and knowledge gained by her lifelong study of volcanoes, Ferriahn sensed a planar rift in the magma of the caldera and that it was somehow causing its twin volcano to become unstable. Troubled, she returned to Dorma after narrowly escaping an encounter with a {@creature fire elemental}.

After some research and prayer, Ferriahn determined that the rift was unstable, and that it's likely that if a certain amount of explosive energy—fire, lightning, thunder, or force—is used in the caldera, it may cause Mount Magra to erupt. Using the {@spell scrying} spell, she observed fiends, dragons, and elementals emerging from the rift, any of which could employ such explosive energies. She believes the planar rift will remain open as long as any of the creatures that came through it survive or remain on this plane—and that closing the rift will render the volcano and caldera dormant once again. If that is not done, she fears the volcano will erupt, causing incredible devastation.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i Hired Heroes.}} Ferriahn met the PCs once and has heard much of their accomplishments since. She casts {@spell sending} to them, imploring them to come to Dorma, offering a reward if the PCs slay the creatures and prevent the eruption. If she finds them honest and forthright, she also offers one {@filter uncommon magic item|items|rarity=uncommon} of the GM's choice.

{@b {@i Local Lineage.}} One or more of the PCs is from the region or even from Dorma itself; or, a PC is descended from the adventurers who slew the dragon and hope to honor their ancestor's sacrifice.
{@b {@i Fire Friend.}} If like Ferriahn, a PC is a worshiper, {@class cleric}, or {@class paladin} of Volund (or a similar faith), they will likely be more motivated to assist her and the town.

entries: Ferriahn is a no-nonsense half-elven cleric of Volund. She's capable, smart, and powerful, but few would describe her as warm. No one has ever doubted her commitment to her faith. She loathes anything that upsets the natural order of mountainous regions, and this certainly qualifies.

She meets the PCs at the village's only tavern, a merry place by the name of the Mountain's Hearth. She informs them of what she knows (see "{@area Adventure Background|19.ab|x}"). If the PCs ask what would happen if the volcano erupts, Ferriahn tells them that everything in a 10-mile radius would be absolutely devastated and thousands of people would likely die.

entries.name: What if the Volcano Erupts?
entries: If the volcano erupts, the eruption lasts two hours, devastating everything in a 10-mile radius. Beyond the initial eruption, lava and gasses continue to leak from the volcano for many weeks afterward.

items: The lava takes two hours to reach the village of Dorma, obliterating everything in its path. See {@area 6|19.6|u} for rules regarding contact with the lava.

All creatures and objects in the affected area take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage from acidic rain. Any creature that takes this damage is {@condition blinded} for 3 ({@dice 1d6}) days unless it succeeds on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. Creatures inside buildings are unaffected unless the acid destroys the building.

After one hour, volcanic hail rains down on the affected area. Treat this as the spell {@spell ice storm} that affects the entire area and deals fire instead of cold damage. Creatures inside buildings are unaffected unless the hail destroys the building.

Each PC must make a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. If more than half of the PCs succeed, they are able to find shelter for their whole party. If less than half succeed, the PCs who succeeded found shelter and can choose whether to use it for themselves or for another PC. Any PC left without shelter takes full damage from the eruption's effects or one with shelter takes half as much. If the Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check succeeds by 5 or more, any PC with shelter takes no damage. Creatures with the ability to move quickly or interdimensionally might be able to escape and potentially bring their allies with them.
Any creatures already on this plane when the volcano erupts are no longer "gated" to the caldera.

entries.name: The Trek to the Mountain
entries: Once the PCs agree to help, Ferriahn remains behind in the town. She intends to stay there to protect it from any marauding monsters that might flee once the PCs begin their efforts. Before they go, she offers to cast {@spell aid} on the entire party (at 4th level) and {@spell death ward} on one PC.

The brief trip from the village of Dorma to the caldera takes you through verdant fields that were enriched by minerals from the volcanic eruption centuries ago. Farmers wave to you as you pass by. One gnome farmer runs up to you with a basket of freshly baked bread and wishes you luck.

entries.name: Travel Trouble
entries: Travel to the mountain takes the PCs 90 minutes on foot or half that if mounted. When they are halfway there, roll {@dice 1d10}. If you roll a 10, roll another {@dice d10} and consult the "Caldera Creatures" table to determine which creatures they encounter. If the PCs drive off—but do not kill—any creatures encountered, those same creatures may show up again as the PCs are closing the gate.

entries.name: The Caldera

entries: Traveling east from Dorma, the road you're traveling ends at the ring of rocky terrain that forms the outer edge of the Sagur caldera. Three hundred feet further east stands Mount Magra, beyond which larger mountains loom. The temperature had been rising imperceptibly as you approached the caldera, but now that you stand on its precipice the heat is now oppressive.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The glow of the lava causes the caldera to be dimly lit. Any area within 5 feet of lava are brightly lit.

entries.name: Volatile Volcano
entries: While the PCs are inside the caldera, tally the amount of thunder, lightning, force, or fire damage dealt by any creature in {@area Areas 2|19.2|x}–{@area 6|19.6|x}, ignoring a creature's immunities or resistances for this purpose. Once that total exceeds 200, Mount Magra erupts. The volcano also erupts if an hour passes before the PCs have defeated all the planar creatures. See the {@area "What if the Volcano Erupts?"|19.wi|x} sidebar for more.

entries.name: Poisonous Gases
entries: The lava in the caldera releases harmful volcanic gases that irritate the eyes and lungs. At the start of each PC's turn that they're inside the caldera, they must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} until the start of their next turn; if the roll failed by 5 or more, the PC is also {@condition blinded}. A PC that fails 3 saving throws (these need not be consecutive) is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. A {@spell lesser restoration} spell removes one of the effects and also removes one failure. A {@spell greater restoration} spell removes both effects and all failures.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/19.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Ground Level
entries: The area surrounding the caldera is rocky terrain, but not difficult to traverse.

entries.name: 2. Caldera Rim

entries: As you crest the rocky rim, you can see the entirety of the caldera before you. On the ledge below stand four large rams with glowing red eyes and flaming hooves. An enormous lava pool sits at the lowest point of the caldera, atop of which writhes a massive serpent, its glassy, obsidian scales shining in the glow of the lava around it. The rams and the serpent are in the midst of an all-out battle.

The outer rim of the caldera rises up in a 15-foot-tall escarpment at a 45 degree angle that comes to a peak, then another 45 degree escarpment descends 15 feet to {@area 3|19.3|u}, back down to the same elevation as {@area 1|19.1|u}. Climbing the outer escarpment requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, which is made with advantage if the PC uses a {@item climber's kit|phb} or gear such as {@item piton|phb|pitons}; no skill check is required to climb down the escarpment. The escarpment is considered difficult terrain.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: See the {@area "Caldera Combat"|19.cc|x} section.

entries.name: 3. Upper Caldera Ledge
entries: This area is a ledge of volcanic rock that encircles the lava pool below. To the north, south, and east, you can see small lava flows that have burst up out of the rock.

entries.name: 4. Lower Escarpment
entries: A 45-degree-angle escarpment descends here, ranging from 10 to 15 feet down, to another ledge below ({@area 5|19.5|u}). For climbing rules, see {@area 2|19.2|u}.

entries.name: 5. Lower Caldera Ledge
entries: A rock ledge that ranges from 3 to 8 feet wide surrounds a pool of lava (see {@area 6|19.6|u}).

entries.name: Extreme Heat
entries: The lava creates extreme heat. A creature without resistance or immunity to fire damage must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw every 10 minutes it spends in Area 5 or suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: 6. Lava Pool
entries: At the center of {@area 5|19.5|u} is a pool of lava 40 long and 25 feet wide. Channels of lava extend away from the pool to other parts of the caldera, with spurs running upward to the northwest, northeast, and south—with the southern spur branching off east and west on the southern section of {@area 3|19.3|u}. These channels have a depth of 1 foot or less, but the central pool itself is extremely deep, leading to an underground channel that connects with Mount Magra.

entries.name: Traversing Lava
entries: If a creature enters or starts its turn in contact with lava, it takes 55 ({@damage 10d10}) fire damage. If a creature starts its turn completely immersed in lava, it takes 99 ({@damage 18d10}) fire damage instead.

entries.name: Avoiding Lava
entries: The lava does not cause contact damage to creatures standing within 5 feet of it, but if that creature begins or ends its turn within 5 feet of it, it must make a DC 15 Constitution save or take {@damage 1d6} points of fire damage from the extreme heat.

entries.name: Touching Lava
entries: Creatures that touch the lava, even for a moment, take {@damage 2d6} fire damage.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Within the caldera, four {@creature ibexian|ToB3|ibexians} are fighting a pitched battle with an {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3}.

items.name: {@i Hampered Foes}
entries: The {@creature ibexian|ToB3|ibexians} have been badly injured in their battle, so they are only at a quarter of their hit point maximum. Also, none of their fire-based abilities affect the {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3}, which also regenerates.
The {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3} is likewise hindered in the battle. Splashing the {@creature ibexian|ToB3|ibexians} with lava is completely ineffective, and they are resistant to its attacks.

items.name: {@i Volatile Energy}
items.entry: When the PCs first arrive on the scene, they see the {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3} use its Lava Splash ability and see one of the {@creature ibexian|ToB3|ibexians}, with the {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3|ophidian} near the edge of the lava pit, charge down the escarpment and use its Pyroclasm ability. Seeing this use of fire damage should force the PCs to intervene immediately. Don't count this damage in the {@area "Volatile Volcano"|19.vv|x} tally and allow the {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3|ophidian} to automatically succeed on recharging its Lava Splash this once.

entries.name: Additional Creatures
entries: Roll {@dice 1d10} at the start of each round of combat. On a 10, roll another d10 on the {@area "Caldera Creatures"|19.table|x} table, rerolling if the result is a creature that the PCs have already encountered during this adventure. The creature bubbles up from the lava and acts at the end of the round. It instinctively knows that its ability to continue roaming this world is dependent on killing the PCs. It cannot leave the area surrounding the caldera unless the volcano erupts.

entries.name: Driven-off Creatures
entries: If the PCs fought one of the creatures on the way to the caldera, but drove it off rather than killing it, that creature (at full health) could appear on a roll of a 10 instead of gating a new creature in.

Also, if all other creatures are slain, a creature the PCs drove off on their way automatically shows up. It's possible the PCs forgot about this creature, leading them to wonder why the volcano is still spouting gases, still ready to explode. But they won't have long to wonder as the previously repelled creature shows up in {@dice 1d6} rounds.

entries.name: Leaving the Caldera
entries: If the PCs leave the caldera, the creatures within follow them, except for the {@creature obsidian ophidian|ToB3}. This is a sound strategy because taking the fight outside the caldera gives them more room to spread out, potentially dividing and conquering their foes. In addition, any energy effects they use outside the caldera that deal fire, lightning, thunder, or force damage do not further destabilize the volcano. Finally, the PCs are not vulnerable to the harmful gases of the caldera while outside it.

entries.name: Enemy Enmity
entries: It's important to remember that most of these creatures are not particularly intelligent and probably don't like each other. If another creature gets in a monster's way or harms them, they have no compunctions about attacking that creature. They also take {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks} against any creature that leaves their reach, except creatures of their same kind.

entries.name: Encounter Difficulty
entries: The encounter at the caldera can prove extremely deadly depending on the encounter table results. Here are some ways to reduce the threat level, should you feel the battle has become too lethal.

items: If you roll a 10 on the encounter table during the battle, simply ignore it.
Have the creatures kill each other. Do this sparingly, but the creatures present might gang up on one of the other creatures. Or it could be that two of the creatures particularly hate each other.
Make the volcanic eruption require more damage to trigger it.

Give the PCs a hint, suggesting they might benefit considerably from drawing the battle away from the caldera. This is particularly reasonable if a PC has the {@skill History} skill or a military or tactical background.

entries: If, however, the encounter proves too easy, here are some ways to amp up the difficulty:

items: Change the die you roll on the encounter table to determine if there's an encounter from a {@dice d10} to a {@dice d8}, or lower the die size by one step each round: {@dice d10}, {@dice d8}, {@dice d6}, {@dice d4}, {@dice d2}. You would still roll a {@dice d10} to determine which creature appears.
Instead of rolling on the encounter table, pick one of the higher CR options.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: Once the PCs have killed or otherwise removed all the creatures in the caldera from this plane, the planar rift closes and the volcanic threat is no more. Ferriahn thanks them profusely, gladly handing over any promised reward.

The PCs have no time to explore the mountain during the adventure, but they may do so afterward. Mount Magra is not detailed here, but if the PCs go there they might encounter more of the creatures described in this adventure. They may find the corpses of the ancient heroes and any treasure they had on them. They might also find the bones of the ancient dragon and possibly its hoard. There might even be a new dragon lairing there, attracted by the brief awakening of the volcano.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 9th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: The Eclipse of the Sun Chapel is a legend shared across generations. In the story, a priesthood devoted to the sun god Khors (see {@i Midgard Worldbook}, or use another god of the sun or light appropriate to your setting) lost their home when ooze cultists attacked during an auspicious solar eclipse. The cult defiled the chapel, creating a planar gate from which oozing horrors spilled forth. Amidst the massacre, a cleric sacrificed themself to seal the portal and block part of the chapel with a magical wall, but the damage was done and the chapel was lost.

Now, a third-generation painter named Pol is visited by an angel who shows him visions of his ancestor at the chapel's fall. The angel then anoints Pol, blessing him with divine authority and proclaiming him an apostle—chosen to reconsecrate the chapel through the working of a miracle. As outlandish as this may seem, Pol accepts his charge with conviction and sets forth on his quest.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: Pol (CG human {@creature apostle|ToB3}), who works miracles through his art, is guided by visions to seek out the PCs and ask for their help. He has nothing with which to pay the PCs, but claims they have been—like he himself—chosen to save the lost chapel. If the PCs demand payment, Pol reluctantly offers them his painting studio, a property in a mountainside town worth approximately 8,000 gp.

When the PCs agree to help, Pol takes them to where he has a horse-drawn cart laden with supplies and declares he is ready to set forth. The ensuing trek takes Pol and the party six days through mountainous terrain before finally reaching the chapel. Complications during the trek are minimal. Pol always seems to know where to go to avoid danger or hostile creatures. When asked about his prescience, Pol simply responds with "I had a vision."

entries.name: The Chapel of the Sun
entries: The Chapel of the Sun faces east on a mountaintop overlooking Pol's hometown. The chapel was built to observe the rising sun and, with its brilliant stained glass windows, was a shining beacon for travelers. The mountain range around the chapel grew rich with alpine berries and flowers which the priests used to make dyes and pigments for blessed works of art.
Pol and the PCs arrive first thing in the morning, just as the sun is rising behind the chapel.

entries.name: The Nave Beckons
entries: Upon arriving at the chapel, Pol leads the PCs directly to {@area 3|20.3|u}, so he can immediately begin his work. He is certain—thanks to his visions—that the nave doesn't contain any creatures, traps, or hazards inside it, and, unwilling to waste any time, he is unwilling to wait for the PCs to clear any rooms. He goes directly to the altar and starts his work on his miracle.

entries.name: The Work Begins
entries: After surveying the nave for several minutes, Pol explains that he will paint a great mural on the wall behind the altar. It will be a triptych, he says, and points out the three central sections of wall between the window panes that he intends to use as his canvas. He believes that the act of observing affects the act of creation, so, through prayer, he learned a subtle magic that he uses to obscure his works until they're finished. Thus, as he paints, the PCs cannot see what he's creating. He insists that he will reveal the work only when it is complete.

entries.name: Desecration
entries: When the cultists attacked the chapel, they ravaged the area; they burned the fields, razed the rectories to the ground, destroyed precious artworks and sacred relics, and smeared slime and ooze into the priests' sacred pigments.
The chapel's desecration causes the following effects:

items: Any creature that doesn't have the elemental, fiend, ooze, or undead type is prevented from traveling within 100 feet of the chapel by teleportation or extradimensional/interplanar means, though short-range teleportation within the grounds, such as via {@spell misty step}, still works.
While on the chapel grounds, whenever a creature's hit points are restored by healing magic, the number of hit points restored is halved. (Hit dice recovery is unaffected.)
Plants cannot grow without magical means within 1 mile of the chapel.

entries.name: Chapel Ceilings
entries: The ceiling of the nave reaches 60 feet in height while all the rest of the ceilings in the chapel are 15 feet high.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/20.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Vestibule

entries: Gobs of ooze, thick with grit, coat most of this vestibule's walls. A table with a crushed alms box stands against the north wall. Opposite a set of ornate double doors is a shallow alcove, grime and muck obscuring it almost entirely.
In addition to the double doors, there's also a single door on the western wall.

entries.name: Mural
entries: In the alcove on the southern wall is a mural, though it is nearly completely hidden behind layers of grime and muck. A pair of small windows shine down from above the mural—or would if they too weren't entirely obscured.

If cleansed (see the {@area "Removing Ooze Grime"|20.rog|x} sidebar), the mural is revealed to be a triptych that depicts: (1) a priest building a mechanical moth; (2) the priest releasing the moth to fly toward the sun; and (3) the priest showing pride at a job well done.

entries.name: Chapel's Defenders
entries: If a PC examines and/or attempts to glean the meaning of the mural, they will be able to repair any deactivated {@creature stained-glass moth|ToB3|stained-glass moths} in the nave ({@area 3|20.3|u}, see {@adventure "Dawn Encounters"|ToB3-Lairs|20|Standing Vigil} section).

entries.name: Removing Ooze Grime
entries: The ooze-based grime used by the cultists to defile the chapel is strangely resistant to prestidigitation and other magic that would otherwise easily remove such filth. But any grime in the chapel can be cleansed by spending 30 minutes continuously using such magic or with one hour of intense scrubbing and/or cleaning (or half as long if a PC is proficient with {@item painter's supplies|PHB} or {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}).

entries.name: 2. Pastor's Chambers

entries: Front and center in this room, a lone skeleton sits slumped over a desk, a large tome under its hand and skull. A closed wardrobe leans against one wall, a fouled wash basin by another. The room is covered in dust, but seems to have escaped the defacement seen in the vestibule.

A successful DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check discovers a (plain, non-magical) steel {@item dagger|phb} under the desk. If a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check is made before anyone touches or jostles the skeleton, it determines, based on the physical evidence, that this person had been stabbed in the back. If the skeleton is jostled at all, it falls apart.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Interacting with the tome on the desk awakens a {@creature gryllus swarm|ToB3|swarm of gryllus} from inside it. If the PCs defeat or calm and befriend the swarm, they gain access to its tome, an illustrated history of the chapel and its clergy. The information within could be useful to Pol, and/or the swarm could be convinced to help the PCs. The swarm does not pursue PCs beyond room 2.

A ragged rug stretches along the length of this room, flanked by twin rows of moldering pews. Three devotional alcoves line the eastern and western walls, inside of which stand pedestals with shattered stained glass littering the floor around them. Two large pulpits at the north end of the enormous chamber stand before the raised altar at the room's far end. Natural light from above filters into the room through in a kaleidoscopic haze from the few intact stained glass windows that remain.

entries.name: The Alcoves
entries: The pedestals in the alcoves on the eastern and western sides of the nave are all bare or smashed, hinting at missing works of art each crafted by a priest.

entries.name: The Altar
entries: The solar burst {@item holy symbol|phb} is broken and covered in grime. A PC who spends an hour cleansing the altar (see the {@area "Removing Ooze Grime"|20.rog|x} sidebar) and succeeds on a DC 17 Intelligence check using {@item tinker's tools|phb} or {@item mason's tools|phb} can reassemble the {@item holy symbol|phb}, which causes it to burst into flame as the {@spell continual flame} spell.

entries.name: Shattered Glass
entries: The piles of shattered glass on the floor are all difficult terrain; a creature can choose to ignore the difficult terrain, but if so it takes {@damage 1d4} slashing damage each 5 feet it moves.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A shelf in the western pulpit holds a ruined worship text. Inside the base of the pulpit is a hidden compartment (that is impossible to see or detect with divination magic) which holds a {@item mace of disruption}; the mace has an additional blessing from the sun god that causes its feature that affects fiends and undead to also affect oozes. The only way to open the compartment is depicted on the alcove wall in {@area 6|20.6|u}; a creature must: (1) light a {@item torch|phb} with the altar's flame; (2) hold the {@item torch|phb} aloft, at which point the light cast by the {@item torch|phb} allows the creature to see the hidden compartment; (3) touching the compartment door while holding the {@item torch|phb} opens it.

entries.name: 4–5. Narthex

entries: This room is separated from the main chapel by a door and decorative half wall. Religious instruments and objects of devotion lie forgotten in corners and cabinets. One cabinet—a wardrobe—holds priestly vestments that crumble if disturbed. In the corner of the room, a staircase leads down into the undercroft, the steps covered in slime trails and footprints from another age.
Areas 4 and 5 are functionally the same. The half wall is 4 feet tall.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The narthices are mostly empty, but a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check in each room finds up to 1,000 gp in material components for divine ritual spells (at the GM's discretion); on a failure, only up to 250 gp is found in each room.

A foul stench permeates this underground corridor, but most striking is the wall of shimmering light that seals closed an archway in the southern wall. The dim light cast by the wall shines on several crates and barrels, a toppled shelf in an oily puddle, and an empty alcove with its walls covered in grime.

entries.name: Mural
entries: A mural is painted along the alcove of the northern wall, though it is obscured behind layers of muck and grime.

If cleansed (see the {@area "Removing Ooze Grime"|20.rog|x} sidebar), the mural is revealed to be a triptych that depicts: (1) a priest kneeling before an altar to light a {@item torch|phb} on its aflame {@item holy symbol|phb}; (2) the priest standing with the {@item torch|phb}—which has now become a mace—raised high, burning with holy fire; and (3) the priest valiantly fighting creatures of the dark with the weapon.

entries.name: Shimmering Wall
entries: The wall is a {@spell wall of force} (as the spell), which can be identified with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check; a creature that can cast {@spell wall of force} automatically succeeds on the check.

entries.name: 7. Sanctum of Saints

entries: Beyond the impassable light barrier is a large chamber shrouded in darkness. Silhouettes in the soft glow of the barrier suggest a circular font in the center, half a dozen pillars, and the chiseled edges of large stone sarcophagi.
A stone sarcophagus sits in each of the alcoves to the east and west—and in the larger alcove to the south. A large circular font occupies the center of the chamber.

entries.name: Font
entries: Currently, the font is an oozing cesspool that subtly roils and is viscerally upsetting to look upon. A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check notices some char marks on the edge of the font, along with the faint, lingering scent of incense in the air, which suggests that it was once used was a focal point of remembrance and contemplation.

entries.name: Sarcophagi
entries: All of the lids of the sarcophagi have been covered in grime, though it is clear that they bear bas-relief carvings on them. If cleansed (see the {@area "Removing Ooze Grime"|20.rog|x} sidebar), the lids of the sarcophagi in the east and west alcoves are revealed to feature bas-relief carvings that depict the sun god's apostles and their good deeds. The lid of the one to the south is more elaborate, with its bas-relief carving also being painted with gold leaf and bright colors.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This catacomb is now both lair and prison to a {@creature sinoper ooze|ToB3} due to the {@spell wall of force} blocking egress into the room (see {@area "Pol's Miracle"|20.pm|x} section).

entries.name: Cesspool
entries: Any creature with the ooze type that starts its turn in the cesspool regains 11 ({@damage 2d10}) hit points.

entries.name: Consecration
entries: Once the {@creature sinoper ooze|ToB3} is defeated, the cesspool bubbles violently and completely evaporates to reveal a bas-relief carving of the sun. Once all of the sarcophagi are cleansed, the sun carving immediately fills the room with holy light.

entries.name: Standing Vigil
entries: Pol's work takes an entire day to complete, during which time the PCs must stand vigil—protecting and providing for Pol—and clear the rooms of the chapel to ensure no unseen dangers lurk.

Mechanically, the PCs' vigil is divided into three phases: Dawn, Day, and Dusk. Each phase lasts 3 hours, during which the PCs experience a set of three encounters. Allow the PCs to take a short rest in between phases and time to explore the chapel as well.

entries.name: 1. Dawn: Enchanted Pigments
entries: Pol points out that there is evidence of enchanted pigments on the walls in the nave and asks the PCs to look around the chapel for more. Each PC must make a DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Religion}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, made with advantage if the PC is proficient with {@item painter's supplies|phb}. Tally the number of successes and consult the "Enchanted Pigments" table to determine what the PCs learn; a higher result finds the items from lower results as well.

entries.caption: Enchanted Pigments
rows: Some of the paints used—antimony, cinnabar, and sinoper—are acidic and poisonous substances that can be fatal if ingested or handled improperly.
The cultists that attacked the chapel stole many of the pigments and spilled the rest in the undercroft.
An ooze absorbed the spilled, toxic pigments, potentially making it more dangerous.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Any PC that succeeds on this roll gains a blessing of inspiration, which allows them to add {@dice 1d4} to one ability check using Charisma.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Six {@creature stained-glass moth|ToB3|stained-glass moths}, high in {@area Area 3's|20.3|x} rafters, activate with the rising sun and immediately attack the PCs. The moths recognize Pol's ancestry and ignore him. After 2 rounds of combat, on initiative count 20, a {@creature gearmass|ToB3} enters from the undercroft. There are moth parts stuck inside the gearmass, causing any remaining moths to ignore it when it arrives. The gearmass is drawn to the PCs and also to any {@condition incapacitated} constructs.

entries.name: Moth Repair
entries: After the moths are reduced to 0 hit points, if a PC has studied the mural in {@area 1|20.1|u}, they can spend 1 hour (or 10 minutes if they're proficient with {@item tinker's tools|phb}) repairing a moth (they're too complicated to repair with the {@spell mending} spell), using spare parts scrapped from two other moths. The moths have been corrupted by the ooze defilement; otherwise they wouldn't have attacked the PCs. The only way to cleanse them of the defilement is to take them outside and release them toward the sun, as in the mural. Any repaired moths remain non-hostile for 1 hour, after which, if they haven't been released toward the sun, they turn violent once again. After being cleansed, any repaired moths return to the rafters in {@area 3|20.3|u} to act as chapel defenders. If the PCs struggle with a combat encounter in {@area 3|20.3|u}, any repaired moths will come to their aid and attack any hostile creatures.

entries.name: 3. Dawn: Mural Modeling
entries: Pol asks the PCs to act as models for his mural. Each PC must make a DC 15 ability check using the skill of their choice. GMs should ask the players to describe what their pose looks like, such as a heroic pose for Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or a magical flourish for Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}). He sketches the poses in a sketchbook to later incorporate into the mural.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Each PC that participates gains the benefit of the {@spell aid} spell for the duration of the vigil.

entries.name: 7. Day: Crisis of Faith
entries: Pol asks the PCs if they believe in the gods. Unsure of where he himself stands even as he works to paint his miracle, Pol is suffering a crisis of faith and needs guidance. The painter is open to hearing all opinions, not just those of trained {@class cleric||clerics} or {@class paladin||paladins}, and wants to hear from each PC.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Any PC that engages with this question with Pol receives the benefit of the {@spell shield of faith} spell for 1 hour.

entries.name: 8. Day: Painter's Block
entries: Pol has hit an artistic block and is desperate for inspiration; he asks the PCs to search the premises for some creative insight. Each PC must make a DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Religion}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, made with advantage if the PC is proficient with {@item painter's supplies|phb}. Tally the number of successes and consult the "Creative Insights" table to determine what the PCs learn; a higher result finds the items from lower results as well.

entries.caption: Creative Insights
rows: There is imagery of warrior angels in the narthices and undercroft. The angels appear harsh, meting out judgments of holy flame and condemnation.
The angels are painted with long dried cinnabar and sinoper pigments and are oriented toward the basement.
The smearing and acidic pockmarking around the images suggests something crawled across the images, taking some of the toxic paint with it.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Any PC that succeeds on this roll gains a blessing of inspiration, which allows them to add {@dice 1d4} to one ability check using Wisdom.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A {@creature copperkill slime|ToB3} enters {@area 1|20.1|u}, spreading itself against the alcove wall. It tries to draw attention to the room by using its pseudopod to grab and throw the nearest heavy object, possibly the alms table if it is still in the room. If this fails to bring anyone within reach of it, the ooze tries to sneak through the chapel to get close enough to a creature to engulf them. If it is still alive after 4 hours or having successfully eaten, it flees the area.

Meanwhile, a {@creature leavesrot ooze|ToB3}, which manifested on the grounds as a result of the chapel's defilement, has entered the chapel through the broken window in {@area 2|20.2|u}. It lies in wait, oozing under the door to attack once the {@creature copperkill slime|ToB3} springs its ambush. The {@creature leavesrot ooze|ToB3} is indistinguishable from a pile of leaves when unmoving, but a PC with a passive {@skill Perception} of 17 or higher notices that some leaves seem to have blown into {@area 2|20.2|u} and are now just visible under the door.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature gray ooze||gray oozes} come up the stairs of {@area Areas 4 and 5|20.4|x}, two on each side.

Once the oozes emerge into {@area 3|20.3|u} to attack, a spirit rises through the altar and steps forward: a {@creature ghost}, the spirit of one of those interred in the undercroft, awoken and corrupted by the ooze defilement. It seeks to defend the chapel from Pol and the PCs and sees the oozes as its allies. It does not use Possession, as it seeks to oust, not control, the intruders. It doesn't know who it was anymore and can't be reasoned with.
After 2 rounds of combat, on initiative count 20, four more {@creature gray ooze||gray oozes} come up the narthex stairs and join the fray.

entries.name: 11. Dusk: Burial Grounds
entries: Pol has another vision, this time of hungry undead clawing and biting him after bursting up from below. He asks the PCs to search the chapel to find if there are dead buried below or on the chapel grounds. Each PC must make a DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Religion}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, made with advantage if the PC has a religious background or one associated with the dead. Tally the number of successes and consult the "Chapel Search" table to determine what the PCs learn; a higher result finds the items from lower results as well.

entries.caption: Chapel Search
rows: There is a graveyard nearby, and the enchantments in place to prevent undead from rising there are still intact.
The room behind the light barrier is called the Sanctum of Saints.
The Sanctum of Saints contains six dead priests and a saint and seems to be the primary source of evil and corruption defiling the chapel.

entries.name: Reward
entries: Any PC that succeeds on this roll gains a blessing of inspiration, which allows them to add {@dice 1d4} to one ability check using Intelligence.

entries.name: 12. Dusk: Fear of Fate
entries: Pol takes one last break to have a small meal with the PCs. At the meal, he confides that he's afraid of what will happen next, what is contained below the chapel, and what his fate will be when his quest concludes. At the end of the meal, Pol has another vision, warning of an undulating horror waiting beneath the chapel that must be destroyed.
After the meal, the PCs have 1 hour to prepare for the final encounter while Pol finishes his work.

entries.name: Reward
entries: The PC that reassures, supports, and engages with Pol the most during this discussion (as adjudicated by the GM) receives the benefits of the {@spell protection from evil and good} spell in perpetuity whenever they are on the chapel grounds; this blessing adds oozes to the creature types affected by the spell.

entries.name: Pol's Miracle
entries: After all four encounter phases are complete, Pol stands and triumphantly states that he is finished and reveals to you his miracle.

Pol's mural is truly an astonishing work, employing vibrant colors and remarkable skill. The triptych, from left to right, depicts the adventure: The PCs arriving at the chapel, a scene showing whichever encounter the players enjoyed the most, and the culmination of their work. The GM is encouraged to try to make it feel meaningful for the players.
After showing off the mural, Pol falls unconscious. Simultaneously, the chapel fills with a brief flash of light as the light barrier in the undercroft is dispelled.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: After the light barrier is dispelled, the {@creature sinoper ooze|ToB3} and two {@creature ochre jelly||ochre jellies} use their Spider Climb and Amorphous abilities to ooze up through the floorboards in the nave and attack. After 5 rounds or when the {@creature sinoper ooze|ToB3} is reduced to half its hit point maximum, it Disengages and retreats, again using its Amorphous ability to slip through cracks in the floorboards to return to {@area 7|20.3|u}, to heal itself within the cesspool.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: When the {@creature sinoper ooze|ToB3} is defeated, all of the remaining evil is driven out, and the chapel's reconsecration is complete. Pol regains consciousness and makes good on any deal agreed upon at the beginning of the adventure. He also blesses some of his leftover paint, gifting it to the PCs. The paint is 1 pot of {@item Nolzur's Marvelous Pigments||marvelous pigments} or {@i interplanar paint} (see {@i Vault of Magic}). Pol remains in the chapel, and within a few months he recruits followers who work to repair the chapel and the priesthood.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 10th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: The Veiled Mannequin is a tailor's shop for discerning customers run by the gnome couturier Yofi Whorthaus. Unbeknownst to the inhabitants of the city, Yofi and her halfling assistant Naver guard the secret entrance to the Twisted Sanctuary, the safehouse of a rakshasa cult hidden in the heart of the city.

The Cult of the Claw secretly corrupts and manipulates city officials as part of a wide-ranging plot designed to enhance their own power and influence. Narga Kan-Sorkis, the leader of the cult, needs several key components to complete a magical pool that will give him the ability to dominate minds from a distance. The cult's rakshasas (and their other minions) have been ordered to acquire the final components at all costs. Over the past three weeks, a spree of vicious crimes has rocked the city, shrouding the otherwise thriving community in a fog of frightened paranoia.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i Missing Child.}} Looking into the kidnapping of a young child, the PCs follow the evidence to the door of the Veiled Mannequin.

{@b {@i Grisly Murder.}} While investigating the crimes in the city, or while involved in other city matters, the PCs come upon the scene of a grisly murder of a city guardsman. A fragment of silk in the dead man's hand is of a type only sold in a few establishments in the city, including the Veiled Mannequin.

{@b {@i Find the Halfling.}} Desperate city officials offer the PCs 500 gp to put a stop to the rash of thefts, murders, and outright terrorism plaguing the city. The only lead they have is the description of a halfling spotted by guardsmen at the scene of three of the incidents. An hour or two spent investigating points the PCs at three halflings fitting the description, including Navar, the apprentice at the Veiled Mannequin.

entries.name: The Veiled Mannequin
entries: An elegantly carved sign above the door reads, "{@style The Veiled Mannequin. Fashions for Discerning Lords, Ladies, and Lieges. Y. Whorthaus, Couturier/Designer.|small-caps}"
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/21.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Showroom

entries: Fanciful dresses and sharp-looking coats hang on racks along the east wall, and three mannequins along the north wall are draped in partially constructed garments. On the long wooden counter to the west are several garments laid out, as well as a book open to a page showing a sketch of a dress design.
This room is the primary workspace and showroom for Yofi Whorthaus.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The proprietor, Yofi (NE {@creature gnome cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs}) and her assistant Naver (NE {@creature halfling cultist|ToB3-Lairs}) can usually be found here during the day. At night, Naver sleeps in a hammock in the Northwest corner while Yofi retires to {@area 2|21.2|u}. Both Yofi and Naver are fanatically loyal to the cult and would never willingly betray any of its secrets.

entries.name: Alarm Stone
entries: If Yofi decides a PC is a threat, she touches a gemstone enchanted with the {@spell alarm} spell that is affixed to the underside of the counter. This silently alerts Narga Kan-Sokris and his right-hand Aliza Sahar to the danger (see {@area Areas 5|21.5|x} and {@area 13|21.13|x}).
This is a small but elegant bedroom with a large wardrobe against the north wall. The bed is covered with a very fine embroidered quilt and feather pillows.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check spots faint scratches on the wooden floor where the wardrobe has slid from left to right. A secret switch inside the wardrobe allows the bulky furniture to roll, revealing a hidden door. A successful DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check finds the switch. The secret door opens to a spiral staircase going down ({@area 3|21.3|u}).

A curving marble staircase winds down the inside curve of a twenty feet wide, eighty feet high, cylindrical shaft that descends deep into the ground. The domed ceiling of the chamber is fashioned to resemble a human face with an open screaming mouth.

entries.name: Rolling Fire Trap
entries: This magical trap activates when one or more creatures steps on the center of the first step. Once triggered, a ball of fire emerges from the mouth on the ceiling and begins rolling down the stairs. Each creature on the stairs must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw; the creature takes {@damage 3d6} fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. The mouth spits additional balls of fire as the PCs descend the stairs; to reach the bottom, each PC must make 3 separate saves. The balls of fire vanish when they reach the foot of the stairs.

A successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices faint glyphs on the stair, which allows the PCs to avoid the trap if they step around it. A successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 13) removes this enchantment.

entries.name: The Twisted Sanctuary
entries: The cultist's lair is richly appointed and elegant, constructed of fine marble, decorated with murals and mosaic tile. Unless noted in the text, none of the doors of the Twisted Sanctuary are locked, and the chambers are brightly illuminated by glowing hanging orbs.

Just beyond the landing of the spiral staircase is a short, wide flight of stairs that leads to grand hall lined with carved stone pillars. The floor is tiled in mosaic patterns, and rich tapestries hang from the walls. At the far side of the room, the hall ends in a large metal door set into an imposing wall carved with tiger heads and images of ritual slaughter.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: When the PCs arrive in this chamber, they discover an {@creature apostle|ToB3} overseeing the training of three {@creature cult fanatic||cult fanatics} and four {@creature cultist||cultists}. If the foes are alerted to the PCs' intrusion (either via the {@spell alarm} in {@area 1|21.1|u} or triggering the trap in {@area 3|21.3|u}), the {@creature apostle|ToB3} and cultists attack immediately. Otherwise, the PCs have surprise.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The cultists are armed with {@item dagger|phb|daggers} and {@item scimitar|phb|scimitars}. Two of the {@creature cult fanatic||cult fanatics} wear pendants made of gold, shaped like a clawed hand, holding a large ruby (worth 1,000 gp each).

entries.name: 5. Audience Hall

entries: A colorfully painted gazebo with four pillars supporting a domed roof sits in the center of the chamber. To the east, a few short steps lead up to a raised nook where a figure in a hooded robe sits atop plush cushions while smoking on a brass hookah. Standing behind and to her left is a tall, tigerfaced woman in scale mail.

Aliza Sahar (LE human {@creature apostle|ToB3}) is tasked with meeting with members and handling the day-to-day operations of the cult. Aliza uses this room for that purpose and also to collect information from the cult's spies. Almost no one is even aware of Narga's existence, believing that Aliza runs the cult. The pair is happy to keep up this ruse, which allows Narga plenty of freedom to carry out his schemes. Unwaveringly loyal to Narga, Aliza attempts to ferret out as much information as she can from any intruders and fights to the death to protect the door that leads deeper into the sanctuary.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Aliza Sahar is a human {@creature apostle|ToB3} with five {@creature myrmidon rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa myrmidons}, one standing behind her, and four lurking inside hidden alcoves in each corner of the chamber; the alcoves allow a creature inside it to see and hear into the room.

entries.name: Locked Door
entries: The door to the north is locked, but can be picked with a successful DC 17 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Beneath the cushions in the raised nook is a small coffer containing a {@item potion of invisibility}.

The walls of this hallway feature beautiful—but upsetting—artwork depicting tiger-headed humanoids oppressing and torturing all manner of other races. A carved pillar stands in the center of an intersection to the north, the floor around it decorated with exquisite mosaic tilework.

entries.name: Pillar Trap
entries: Snarling tiger heads decorate each face of this diamond shaped pillar. Any non-rakshasa that steps on the mosaic floor around the pillar (10 foot radius) must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or suffers the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute; any creature wearing a ruby claw pendant (see {@area 4|21.4|u}) automatically succeeds on the saving throw. A successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices glyphs hidden on the mosaic tiling on the floor. A successful {@spell dispel magic} (DC 14) removes this enchantment for 1 hour.
Boxes and crates line the walls of this chamber, as well as a row of crates down the center of the room.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature servitor rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa servitors} labor here. They attempt to flee to {@area 8|21.8|u} if confronted, taking the {@action Disengage} and/or {@action Dash} action if necessary.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The crates contain supplies of food, wine, mundane gear, and construction supplies. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check uncovers a leather bound {@item spellbook|phb} (see Development) in an unlocked chest. The incantations in the book appear to be formulae for the following spells: {@spell dominate person}, {@spell disintegrate}, {@spell finger of death}, {@spell dominate monster}, {@spell power word kill} and {@spell wish}.

entries.name: Development
entries: The tome is actually a {@creature pustakam rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa pustakam} who was napping in book form when the PCs entered. The fiend waits until it is in the possession of a PC, then, at an opportune moment, it uses its {@spell suggestion} and {@spell dominate person} spells to sow chaos among the party.

entries.name: 8. Lakeside Quarters

entries: The damp air in this room is heavy with the heady scent of incense, strange spices, and the metallic tinge of blood. Embroidered fabrics line the walls, arching up to gather near the ceiling, giving the interior a pavilion-like facade. Piles of rich cushions festoon the area, with elegant side tables groaning beneath the weight of full wine pitchers, platters of sweetmeats, scattered playing cards, candied fruits, and curried meats on long skewers. The northern wall of the chamber is a series of arches and pillars, draped with diaphanous silks, opening onto the shore of an underground lake.
When not disguised as mortals and advancing their foul plots or participating in evil rituals, the rakshasa member of the cult lounge here, waited on by lesser rakshasas and {@creature imp||imps}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Six {@creature myrmidon rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa myrmidons} lounge here, waited on by three {@creature servitor rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa servitors} and two {@creature imp||imps}. If warned by the servitors in {@area 7|21.7|u}—or by any active fighting in {@area 6|21.6|u}—the rakshasas lurk along the southern wall, ready to ambush the PCs. Otherwise, they relax in the chamber, feasting and drinking.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A search of the area finds 5 bottles of very fine wine (worth 500 gp total). {@dice 1d6} of the playing cards found on the various tables are random cards from a {@item deck of illusions}.

entries.name: 9. Underground Lake

entries: The midnight water flows from the northeast into a huge cavern, pooling in a deep, murky lake, before sweeping outward to the southwest.
Apart from the tiny rocky shore along the northern edge of {@area 8|21.8|u}, the walls of the cavern drop vertically to the bottom of the lake.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Five {@creature bearded devil||bearded devils} and three {@creature imp||imps} inhabit the lake and attack any creature foolish enough to enter their domain.

entries.name: Illusion
entries: The cavern wall to the northwest is an illusion that hides the dock in {@area 14|21.14|u}. A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check against DC 16.

entries.name: Development
entries: A successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices a golden glow emanating from something at the bottom of the lake 15 feet from the shore of {@area 8|21.8|u}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The rakshasas threw a {@item gem of brightness} into the lake after they failed to corrupt it. The item lies at a depth of 15 feet.

entries.name: 10. Stone Bridge

entries: A graceful bridge arches across a subterranean river here. Crystals atop a pair of pillars on each side of the span shine with an orange light, casting distorted reflections on the black waters below.
The crystals shine with a {@spell continual flame} spell but are otherwise merely decorative.

entries.name: 11. The Chiropteran Stepwell

entries: A huge, inverted step pyramid descends three levels down to a circular dais topped with two rings of freestanding, ornamentally decorated pillars. Each step is 15 feet below the one above it, the final level resting 50 feet beneath the ceiling of the chamber. An archway on the northern wall is carved to resemble a snarling tiger's head with a large metal door set into its mouth. The air in the chamber bears the musky scent of incense and guano.

The cult's spymasters, Chiaana and Sunana (NE {@creature half-elf atavist|ToB3-Lairs|half-elf atavists}), keep their colony of bats in this large chamber. Together they raise and care for the bat colony, hand-feeding and training the bats daily. As such, the bats understand and follow basic orders, such as to attack a specific target, from the twins, who need only speak single-word commands (no action required) to direct the bats.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Chiaana and Sunana hide on the ceiling alongside their bat companions (twelve {@creature swarm of bats||swarms of bats}), using their Malleable Physiology trait to sprout fleshy, membranous wings from their shoulders.

entries.name: Dais
entries: The mosaic tiles at the center of the dais form a sliding tile puzzle. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check spots the missing tile that begins the puzzle. Solving the puzzle requires a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, and the revealed image depicts a tiger's head. When the puzzle is solved, a niche opens on one of the pillars, revealing a lever that unlocks the door in the northern wall.

entries.name: Metal Door
entries: This door is secured with an {@spell arcane lock} spell (DC 25) but can be unlocked by pulling the levers revealed when one solves the puzzle.

Mosaic tiles cover the floor of this long hallway in intricate patterns and colors while glowing orbs shine down from recesses in the arched ceiling and stone reliefs of tiger's heads snarl out from the walls.

entries.name: 13. The Tiger's Eye

entries: Tall pillars support the cavernous ceiling of this ornate chamber. An oval pool of viscous, reddish brown liquid glows in the center of the room, at the foot of a wall of rich crimson velvet drapery bisecting the chamber. Steep mosaicked stairs lead 15 feet up to a platform covered with glowing runes. A semicircular dais overlooks the glowing liquid from the other side of the pool.
Narga Kan-Sorkis labors to construct his domination pool in this chamber. It is incomplete still and he fights to the death to protect it.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: {@creature Narga Kan-Sorkis|ToB3-Lairs} (LE {@creature slayer rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa slayer}), waits here to attack the interlopers—{@condition invisible||invisibly} if the PCs have been detected. Two {@creature myrmidon rakshasa|ToB3|rakshasa myrmidons} lurk behind the curtains, attacking if they hear their master in danger.

entries.name: Legendary Actions
entries: Narga can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Narga regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

items: {@b {@i Teleport.}} Narga magically teleports to an unoccupied space he can see within 60 feet of him.
{@b {@i Restorative.}} Narga recovers 7 ({@dice 2d6}) hit points.

{@b {@i Fetch (Costs 2 Actions).}} Narga summons a {@creature servitor rakshasa|TOB3|rakshasa servitor}. It appears in an unoccupied space Narga can see within 30 feet and acts on his initiative count.

{@b {@i Whelm (Costs 3 Actions).}} A pseudopod of magical liquid lashes out from the pool. A target within 30 feet of the pool must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 13 ({@damage 3d8}) bludgeoning damage. If it is Large or smaller, it is also {@condition grappled} (escape DC 15). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and unable to breathe unless it can breathe water. The pool can only grapple one creature at a time.

entries.name: Curtain
entries: Beyond the velvet curtain is Narga's palatial living quarters. A secret door in the eastern wall—which is detected with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check—leads to {@area 14|21.14|u}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Narga keeps his greatest treasures on display in his living quarters including: a {@item wand of magic detection}, an ornate {@item dagger of venom}, and a {@item circlet of blasting}. An open coffer holds 4,230 gp in assorted coins. The various works of art and rich furnishings could bring 7,810 gp to the right buyer. A table covered with papers could offer important information on local nobles or officials (at the GMs discretion).

entries.name: 14. Hidden Dock

entries: This small natural grotto features a small wooden dock that reaches out onto the dark water. A 15-foot-long wooden skiff floats next to it.
Narga keeps this vessel here in case he needs to make a hurried escape from the lair.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The boat is actually a {@item folding boat}, though it only produces a 15 foot craft without a deck cabin.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: The adventure ends when the PCs defeat Narga. They are given the appropriate reward for their efforts, depending on the hook used to begin the quest. However, thwarting Narga brings the PCs to the attention of the other rakshasa cults, and if there is one thing the fiends know, it's revenge.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 11th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: A strange, black horse draped in silver chains has been seen in the woods and fields around the small farming village of Derrymead. The locals claim it is a {@creature púca|ToB3}, and they're certain it will run off with their children. More concerning, however, is the group of cultists trying to get their hands on the {@creature púca|ToB3} and use it to gain access to the other planes. The cultists have claimed an old barrow near Derrymead for themselves and scour the roads and forests day and night in hopes of finding the beast.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i Heroes Wanted.}} A flyer requests brave heroes to help rid the town of Derrymead of a frightening creature that endangers the town's children.
{@b {@i Hail Traveler.}} A farmer from Derrymead hauling a cartful of goods meets the PCs on the road and passes on the information about the {@creature púca|ToB3}.
{@b {@i Just Passing Through.}} The PCs are passing through Derrymead and stop at the Fallows, Derrymead's inn.

entries: No matter how the PCs arrive in Derrymead, they're directed to the Fallows to speak with the innkeeper, Felicity Dunn.

entries.name: Derrymead
entries: Derrymead is a small town surrounded by farms and fields that are wild and often . . . strange. The farmers do their best to push back the forest and cultivate the land, but danger constantly lurks in those woods. The folk are hardy and strong, but hold tight to superstitions and folktales to keep themselves and their children safe. The town itself consists mainly of a town square with a few small shops and the Fallows Tavern and Inn.

entries.name: The Fallows Tavern and Inn
entries: The Fallows Tavern and Inn is a modest establishment in the tiny town square of Derrymead. It boasts but six tables and has three rooms for rent. A notice board just inside the door sports scraps of paper looking for help with hauling wood or sowing grain—and the flyer described in the "Heroes Wanted" adventure hook; it directs interested parties to speak to the proprietor of the inn, Felicity Dunn (NG human {@creature commoner}), who is a handsome woman of middle years with dark skin and curly black hair.

entries.name: What Felicity Knows
entries: A strange black horse draped in silver chains was first spotted in the woods outside of town four weeks ago. The eerie, cold light in the beast's eyes hinted that it is not of this world, and some of the farmers are convinced it's a {@creature púca|ToB3}—a corrupted fey steed that lures innocents onto its back and then rides off with them.

A week ago, several strange, robed figures appeared nearby town and began roaming the woods day and night as if hunting something. People say that their eyes are pure black but with specks of light in them, like a starry sky. Felicity doesn't know who they are, but she's sure they're here because of the creature—though whether they're working with the beast or against it, she doesn't know. Even more troubling: Three days ago, the blacksmith's son, Auri Rorsk, saw one of the robed figures while walking the road to town with his sister. The fool boy confronted the stranger, and, well . . . his mind hasn't been the same since. She doesn't know more than that about Auri, but suggests that perhaps the boy's sister Leena might be able to tell them more.

The farmers have managed to pool together a pouch of 500 gp as payment for anyone able to kill or drive off these frightening strangers. Additionally, one of the farmers is offering up his grandfather's {@item dwarven plate||dwarven plate armor} as a reward if the adventurers can rid the town of the {@creature púca|ToB3}—or whatever the creature is—as well.

entries.name: The Cult and the Púca
entries: The cult is enthralled by an entity known as the Astral Rider, who is said to ride a majestic black steed across the Astral Plane, driving all he encounters mad. They're convinced that capturing the {@creature púca|ToB3} will please their patron.

entries.name: Encountering the Cultists
entries: Any time the PCs venture into the woods or fields around Derrymead, there is a chance they encounter wandering cultists searching for the {@creature púca|ToB3}. The cultists are hostile and cannot be reasoned with, immediately attacking the PCs. Their faces are all pale and drawn, and their eyes are as Felicity described.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If the PCs are out during the day, roll {@dice 1d10}. On a result of 1–5, the PCs encounter that number of {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics}. If the PCs are out at night, they encounter a more robust group pursuing the {@creature púca|ToB3} (see the {@area "Encountering the Púca"|22.etp|x} section).

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: Any {@creature cult fanatic||cult fanatics} the PCs encounter in this adventure have {@sense darkvision} (60 ft.) and the following changes to their spell list: replace {@spell sacred flame} with {@spell eldritch blast}; replace {@spell shield of faith} with {@spell bane}; and replace {@spell spiritual weapon} with {@spell darkness}.

entries.name: Questioning the Cultists
entries: Interrogating a {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatic} is tricky business. For every minute the PCs attempt to question one, roll a {@dice d20}. On a result of 1–5, the {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatic} spends the next minute lost in their madness; they cannot answer questions (instead, they babble incomprehensibly or wail or stare into the distance), and spells like {@spell detect thoughts} reveal nothing but otherworldly shrieking. If a spell such as {@spell calm emotions} is used, reroll the {@dice d20}.

entries.name: Encountering the Púca
entries: If the PCs venture into the woods and fields at night, they encounter the {@creature púca|ToB3}. A successful DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows a PC to hear the clinking of the chains before the creature emerges from the trees.

entries.name: If the Púca Spots the PCs
entries: It approaches them at a walk, waiting for one of the PCs to climb onto its back. It only attacks the PCs if they are hostile.

entries.name: If the PCs Hide From the Púca
entries: It continues slowly on its way. Three rounds later, five {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics} wearing iron spurs arrive in the company of a {@creature cult thaumaturge|ToB3-Lairs} (use statistics for {@creature mage} with the changes noted below) atop a {@creature leashed lesion|ToB3}. The cultists attack the PCs if they intervene, but otherwise ignore them and chase after the {@creature púca|ToB3}.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: The {@creature cult thaumaturge|ToB3-Lairs} has {@sense darkvision} (60 ft.), AC 16 ({@item breastplate|phb}), and the following changes to its spell list: replace {@spell fire bolt} with {@spell eldritch blast}; replace {@spell mage armor} with {@spell hellish rebuke}; replace {@spell misty step} with {@spell darkness}; replace {@spell fly} with {@spell hypnotic pattern}; and replace {@spell cone of cold} with {@spell hold monster}.

entries.name: If the PCs Do Not Intervene
entries: The {@creature cult thaumaturge|ToB3-Lairs} uses {@spell hold monster} on the {@creature púca|ToB3}, then commands one of the {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics} to mount it. They then proceed back to their home base (see {@adventure "The Barrow"|ToB3-Lairs|22|The Barrow} section) with the creature.

entries.name: If the PCs Attack the Cultists
entries: The {@creature púca|ToB3} fights alongside the PCs (unless they attack it as well). If any of the {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics} mount the púca during the combat, they flee with the creature back to the barrow, having gotten what they came for.
If, at any time while fighting the cultists or the PCs, the {@creature púca|ToB3} drops to one-quarter of its health (42 hit points) or lower, it flees.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Along with the items assigned to them by their statblock, the cultists each wear a pair of iron spurs.

entries.name: Visiting the Farms
entries: The PCs can visit any of the local farms to attempt to gain more information on the {@creature púca|ToB3} and/or the cultists. There are twenty farms within a day's travel of Derrymead. Any of the farmers questioned only know what Felicity knows, though they direct the PCs to Mell Rorsk—the town blacksmith, whose son encountered one of the cultists on the road.

entries.name: The Blacksmith
entries: Mell Rorsk is Derrymead's blacksmith. She lives not far from the town center, in a small house with her husband Jorun, and her 16-year-old son Auri and 14-year-old daughter Leena. Auri was struck with madness when he confronted one of the wandering cultists on the road three days ago. He hasn't recovered, and he now spends all his time in his bedroom, staring blankly out the window. If the PCs wish to ask any questions about Auri's encounter, Mell directs them to Leena, who was with the boy when he met the cultist.

A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check determines that the madness afflicting Auri can be cured by the {@spell lesser restoration} spell and that, otherwise, he should recover after 7 days have passed.

entries.name: What Leena Knows
entries: Leena is an impulsive teenager, with a stubborn streak and a lingering sense of guilt over her brother's current condition. If asked about the encounter with the cultist, she tells them the following:

Leena and Auri were walking from their home toward town for market day when they spotted a cloaked, hooded figure in a copse of trees by the road. Having heard the fearful rumors about these hooded strangers lurking in the woods, Auri drew his sword and advanced on the figure. The man turned toward him, and a moment later Auri fell to the ground, clutching his head and screaming. Leena only got a glimpse of the man's face—it was pale and drawn, and his eyes were like a starry night sky. Rivulets of blood ran from his eyes and down his cheeks. The experience was terrifying, but she is angry and ready to fight—though her parents won't let her.

A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check reveals that Leena is not being completely honest about the situation. If pressed, a successful DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion}) check forces her to break down and admit she's the one who advanced on the figure initially—her brother wanted to turn back and get their parents, but Leena wanted to confront the individual—and her brother paid the price for it. She knows nothing else.

entries.name: Iron Spurs
entries: If the PCs tell Mell they are hoping to drive off the {@creature púca|ToB3} as well as the cultists, she provides them with two sets of iron spurs. She tells them her grandmother always said the creature despised iron, and, that by wearing the spurs, the PCs might be able to control the {@creature púca|ToB3}. She apologizes—she'd offer more, but someone recently ransacked her forge and stole the other five sets of spurs she'd already made.

entries.name: The Barrow
entries: The barrow is an old burial site located roughly an hour west of Derrymead. It has been mostly forgotten by the locals, as it was sealed generations ago, but the cultists discovered it and have claimed it as their own.
The barrow has several features that are common throughout:

entries.name: Stone Doors
entries: The doors within are thick, gray granite. Each door has 17 AC, 27 hit points, and a damage threshold of 10. They can be pushed open with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Domed Ceilings
entries: The roof of each chamber is curved like the inside of a dome. Each ceiling is made of stacked stone, is 10 feet tall where it meets the wall, and rises 15 feet tall at its apex.

entries.name: Earthen Walls
entries: The walls are made of stacked stone, behind which lies the dirt of the mound itself. The walls and ceiling are reinforced with wooden beams.

entries.name: Torchlit
entries: Each of the three main rooms has {@item torch|phb|torches} mounted in sconces along the wall, every 15 feet or so. All the torches are lit, causing the main three rooms to be brightly lit. They are easily removed from the sconces.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/22.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Entryway
entries: This hallway is 20 feet long and 10 feet wide and is bracketed by double doors. There is no light source here.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: If any of the {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics}, the {@creature cult thaumaturge|ToB3-Lairs}, or the {@creature leashed lesion|ToB3} escaped from the earlier encounter (see the {@area "Encountering the Púca"|22.etp|x} section), the PCs encounter them as they exit the barrow.

entries.name: 2. First Ritual Chamber
entries: This round chamber measures roughly 40 feet in diameter. In the center of the room is a stone dais upon which sits a 3-foot-tall, 8-foot-diameter stone brazier. The bowl of the brazier looks to be lined with iron, and it is cold and unlit. Double doors to the north lead to {@area 3|22.3|u}, and four single doors lead to {@area Areas 5, 6, 7, and 8|22.5|x}.

entries.name: 3. Second Ritual Chamber
entries: This room is nearly identical to {@area 2|22.2|u}, with one exception: A portion of the southeastern wall and ceiling has caved in, exposing the dirt of the mound above. Thin roots poke through the dirt like withered, pale fingers. Piles of stone and dirt lie beneath the holes; these areas are considered difficult terrain. Double doors to the north lead to {@area  4|22.4|u}, and four single doors lead to {@area Areas 9, 10, 11, and 12|22.5|x}.

entries.name: 4. Third Ritual Chamber
entries: In this room, a portion of the ceiling to the east has fallen in, causing that area to be difficult terrain. Five single doors lead to {@area Areas 13, 14, 15, 16, and 17|22.5|x}.

This circular chamber is nearly identical to the others, ringed by single stone doors. To the east, a portion of the ceiling has fallen in, and debris lies in a mound beneath the hole. Whereas in the other chambers, the braziers were cold, this one burns with a searing-bright green and purple flame, lighting several figures behind it in stark relief.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Standing before the brazier on the far side of the room are three {@creature Astral Rider cult fanatic|ToB3-Lairs|cult fanatics} and the cult's leader Cae Kel Dranus (LE human {@creature psychophant|ToB3} cultist).
If the cultists captured the {@creature púca|ToB3}, it is present as well; if so, add the following to the read-aloud text above:
And standing before you, bound by its own chains to the brazier, is the púca, its head hanging low.

entries.name: Cultist Conversation
entries: When the PCs enter the room, Dranus raises one hand to keep her cultists from attacking, and invites the PCs in to talk. If they do, she explains the following:

items: She and her people are only here for the {@creature púca|ToB3}.
They have no quarrel with the farm folk or the PCs.
If the PCs killed any of her cultists, she magnanimously forgives them such transgressions.
She and her people will leave as soon as they have the {@creature púca|ToB3}—or, if they already have the {@creature púca|ToB3}, they'll leave as soon as she has it fully under her thrall.
